editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Presented to the King and Queen at Whitehall.
Acted since at Blackfriars by his majesty's servants.

quote.p: Versibus exponi tragicis res comica non vult.

div.p: Oxford, printed by Leonard Lichfield, printer to the university.

sp.l: , Seathrift, never yet
Brought forth the like; i would have them that have
Fined twice for sheriff mend it.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Mend it? Why
'Tis passed the wit oth' court of aldermen.
Next merchant tailor that writes chronicles
Will put us in.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: For, since I took him home,
Though, sir, my nephew, as you may observe,
Seem quite transfigured, be as dutiful
As a new prentice; in his talk declaim
'Gainst revelling companions, be as hard
To be enticed from home as my door posts ▪
This reformation may but be his part,
And he may act his virtues. I have not
Forgotten his riots at the temple. You know sir—

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: You told me Mr. Warehouse.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Not the sea
When it devoured my ships cost me so much
As did his vanities. A voyage to th' Indyes
Has been lost in a night. His daily suits
Were worth more than the stock that set me up.
For which he knew none but the silkman's book,
And studied that more than the law. He had
His loves too, and his mistresses; was entered
Among the philosophical madams, was
As great with them as their concerners, and I hear
Kept one of them in pension.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: My son too
Hath had his errors; I could tell the time
When all the wine which I put off by whole sale
He took again in quarts, and at the day
Vintners have paid me with his large scores. But
He is reformed too.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Sir, we now are friends
In a design.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: And hope to be in time
Friends in alliance, sir.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: I'll be free,
I think well of your son.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Who, Timothy?
Believe't a virtuous boy, and for his sister
A very saint.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Mistake me not, I have
The like opinion of my nephew, sir,
Yet he is young, and so is your son, nor
Doth the church-book say they are passed our fears.
Our presence is their bridle now: 'tis good
To know them well whom we do make our heirs.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: It is most true.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Well, and how shall we know
How they will use their fortune, or what place
We have in their affection without trial?
Some wise men build their own tombs, let us try
If we were dead whether our heirs would cry,
Or their long cloaks: this plot will do't.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: 'Twill make us
Famous upon the exchange for ever. I'll home
And take leave of my wife and son.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: And I'll
Come to you at your garden house ▪ within there. Ex. Seath.

div.head: Scaena ii.
div.l: Now cypher, where's my nephew?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: In the hall
Reading a letter which a footman brought
Just now to him from a lady sir.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: A lady?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Yes, sir, a lady in distress; for I
Could overhear the fellow say she must
Sell her coach horses, and return again
To her needle, if your nephew not supply her
With money.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: This is some honourable seamstress.
I'm now confirmed: they say he keeps a lady,
And this is she. well cypher, 'tis too late
To change my project now. Be sure you keep
A diary of his actions, strictly mark
What company comes to him, if he stir
Out of my house observe the place he enters.
Watch him till he come out: follow him disguised
To all his haunts.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: He shall not want a spy sir.
But sir when you are absent if he draw not
a lattice to your door, and hang a bush out —

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: I hope he will not make my house a tavern.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Sir I'm no sibyl's son.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Peace here he comes. Enter Plotwell in a sad posture.

div.head: Scaena iii.
div.l: Good morrow nephew: how now? sad? how comes
This melancholy?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Can I choose but wear
Clouds in my face when I must venture, sir,
Your reverend age to a long doubtful voyage
And not partake your dangers?

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Fie, these fears
Though they become you, nephew, are ominous.
When heard you from your father?

sp.speaker: Plotw:
sp.l: Never since
He made the escape sir.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: I hear he is in Ireland:
Is't true he took your sister with him?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: So
Her mistress thinks, sir, one day she left the exchange,
And has not since been heard of.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: And nephew
How like you your new course? which place prefer you
The temple or exchange? where are, think you,
The wealthier mines in the Indies, or
Westminster hall?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Sir my desires take measure
And form from yours.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Nay tell me your mind plainly,
Ith' city tongue. I'd have you speak like cypher.
I do not like quaint figures, they do smell
Too much o'th inns of court.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Sir, my obedience
Is ready for all impressions which —

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Again?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Sir I prefer your kind of life, a merchant

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: 'Tis spoken like my nephew: now I like you.
Nor shall I ere repent the benefits
I have bestowed, but will forget all errors,Exit Cyph.
As mere seducements: and will not only be
An uncle but a father to you: but then
You must be constant, nephew.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Else I were blind
To my good fortune, sir.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Think man how it may
in time make thee oth' city senate, and raise thee ▪
To th' sword and cap of maintenance.

sp.speaker: (Plotw.
sp.l: Yes, and make me
Sentence light bread, and pounds of butter on horseback.)

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Have gates and conduits dated from thy year ▪
Ride to the spittle on thy free beast.

sp.speaker: (Plotw.
sp.l: Yes,
Free of your company.)

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Have the people veil
As low to his trappings as if he thrice had fined
For that good time's employment.

sp.speaker: (Plotw.
sp.l: Or as if
He had his rider's wisdom.)

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Then the works
And good deeds of the city to go before thee,
Besides a troop of varlets.

sp.speaker: (Plotw.
sp.l: Yes, and I
To sleep the sermon in my chain and scarlet.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: How say you? Let's hear that.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I say, sir, I
To sit at sermon in my chain and scarlet.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: 'Tis right, and be remembered at the cross.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: And then at sessions, sir, and all times else,
Master Recorder to save me the trouble,
And understand things for me.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: All this is possible,
And in the stars and winds: therefore dear nephew,
You shall pursue this course, and to enable you
In this half year that I shall be away,
cypher shall teach you French, Italian, Spanish,
And other tongues of traffic

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Shall i not learn
Arithmetic too, sir, and shorthand?

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: 'Tis well
Remembered, yes, and navigation. Enter cypher.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Sir, Mr. Seathrift says you will lose the tide,
The boat stays for you.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Well, nephew, at my return
As i hear of your carriage, you do know
What my intentions are; and for a token
How much I trust your reformation,
Take this key of my countinghouse, and spend
Discreetly in my absence. Farewell. Nay
No tears ▪ I'll be here sooner than you think on't
cypher you know what you have to do.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: I warrant you, sir.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Tears? yes my melting eyes shall run, but itExit
Shall be such tears as shall increase the tide
To carry you from hence.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Come Mr. Plotwell shall I
Read to you this morning.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Read what? how the price.
Of sugar goes, how many pints of olives
Go to a jar, how long wine works at sea,
what difference is in gain between fresh herrings
And herrings red?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: This is fine, ha you
Forgotten your uncle's charge?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Prithee what was't?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: To learn the tongues and mathematics.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Troth
If I have tongue enough to say my prayers
Ith' phrase oth' kingdom i care not; otherwise
I'm for no tongues but dried ones, such as will
Give a fine relish to my bacharach; and for mathematics,
I hate to travail by the map, methinks Enter ▪ bright and Newcut.
'Tis riding post.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: I knew 'twould come to this.
Here be his comrades.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: What my Fleetstreet friends?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Save you merchant Plotwell.

sp.speaker: Newc.
sp.l: Mr. Plotwell
Citizen and merchant, save you.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Is thy uncle
Gone the wished voyage?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Yes, he's gone, and if
He die by th' way hath bequeathed me but some
Twelve hundred pound a year in Kent, some three -
Score thousand pound in money, besides jewels, bonds,
And desperate debts.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: And dost not thou fall down
And pray to th' winds to sacrifice him to
Poor John and mackerel?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Or invoke some rock
To do thee justice?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Or some compendious canon
To take him off ith' middle?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: And why my tender
Soft-hearted friends?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: What to take thee from the temple
To make thee an old juryman, a Whittington?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: To transform thy plush to pennystone, and scarlet
Into a velvet jacket which hath seen
Aleppo twice, is known to the great Turk,
Hath scaped three shipwracks to be left off to thee,
And knows the way to Mexico as well as the map?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: This jacket surely was employed in finding
The north-east passage out. Or the same jacket
That Coryat died in.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: In Ovid
There is not such a metamorphosis
as thou art now. To be turned into a tree
Or some handsome beast is courtly to this.
But for thee, Frank, oh transmutation!
Of satin changed to kersey hose I sing.
Slid his shoes shine too.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: They have the Gresham die.
Dost thou not dress thyself by 'em? I can see
My face in them hither.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Very pleasant gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: And faith for how many years art thou bound?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Do you take me for a prentice?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Why then what office
Dost thou bear in the parish this year? Let's feel,
No batteries in thy head to signify
Thou'rt constable?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: No furious jug broke on it
In the King's name?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Did you contrive this scene
By the way gentlemen?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: No, but the news
Thou shouldst turn tradesman, and this pagan dress,
In which if thou shouldst die thou wouldst be damned
For an usurer, is comical at the temple.
We were about to bring in such a fellow
For an apostate in our antimasque.
Set one to keep the door, provide half-crown rooms,
For I'll set bills up of thee, what shall I
Give thee for the first day?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Ay, or second?
For thou'lt endure twice or thrice coming in.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Well my conceited orient friends, bright offsprings
Oth' female silkworm, and tailor male I deny not
But you look well in your unpaid for glory.
That in these colours you set out the strand,
And adorn Fleetstreet. That you may laugh at me
Poor working day oth' city, like two festivals
Escaped out of the almanac.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Sirrah bright,
Didst look to hear such language beyond Ludgate?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: I thought all wit had ended at Fleet-bridge.
But wit that goes oth' the score, that may extend
If't be a courtier's wit into Cheapside.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Your mercer lives there does he? I warrant you
He has the patience of a burned heretic:
The very faith that sold to you these silks
And thinks you'll pay for 'em is strong enough
To save the infidel part oth' world, or Antichrist.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: We're most mechanically abused.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Let's tear
his jacket off.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: A match take that side

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: How frail a thing old velvet is, it partsThey tear off his jacket
With as much ease and willingness as two cowards.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: The tenderest weed that ever fell asunder.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Ha you your wits? what mean you?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Go, put on
One of thy temple suits and accompany us,
Or else thy dimity breeches be mortal.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: You will
Not strip me will you?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: By thy visible ears we will.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: By this two handed beaver; which is so thin
And light a butterfly's wings put to't would make it
A Mercuries flying hat and soar aloft.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: But do you know to how much danger
You tempt me? should my uncle know I come
Within the air of Fleetstreet —.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Will you make
Yourself fit for a coach again, and come
Along with us?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Well my two resolute friends
You shall prevail. But whether now are your
Lewd motions bent?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: We'lldine at Roseclap's, there
We shall meet captain Quartfield, and his poet,
They shall show us another fish.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: But by the way we have agreed to see.
A lady, you mechanic.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: What lady?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Hast
Not thou heard of the new-sprung lady?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: One
That keeps her coachman, footboy, woman, and spends
A thousand pound a year by wit.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: How? wit?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: That is her patrimony, sir; 'tis thought
The fortune she is born to will not buy
A bunch of turnips.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: She is no gamester is she?
Nor carries false dice?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: No, but has a tongue,
Wert in a lawyer's mouth, would make him buy
All young heirs near him.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: But does no man know
From whence she came?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: As for her birth she may
Choose her own pedigree; it is unknown
Whither she be descended of some ditch,
Or Duchess.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: She's the wonder of the court,
And talk oth' town.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Her name?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I've heard of her. They say she does fight duels,
And answers challenges in wit.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: She has been
Thrice in the field.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Ith' the field?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Yes, in spring garden.
Has conquered with no second but her woman.
A Puritan, and has returned with prizes.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: And no drum beat before her?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: No, nor colours
Flourished. She has made a vow never to marry
Till she be won by stratagem.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I long
To see her.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Ith' name of Guildhall who comes here?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: By your leave gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Mr. Timothy!
Welcome from the new world. I looked you should
Ha passed through half the signs in heaven by this.
And ha' conversed with dolphins. What not gone
To sea with your father?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: No faith, I do not love
To go to sea, it makes one lousy, lays him
In wooden sheets, and lands him a preservative
Against the plague. Besides, my mother was
Afraid to venture me.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Believe't she's wise,
Not to trust such a wit to a thin frail bark
Where you had sailed within three inches of
Becoming a Jonas. Besides the tossing, to have
All the fierce blustering faces in the map
Swell more tempestuously upon you then
Lawyers preferred, or trumpeters. And whither
Were you bound now?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I only came to have
Your judgement of my suit.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Surely the tailor
Has done his part.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And my mother has done hers,
For she has paid for't. I never durst be seen
Before my father out of Duretta and serge.
But if he catch me in such paltry stuffs,
To make me look like one that lets out money,
Let him say Timothy was born a fool.
Before he went he made me do what he list;
Now he's abroad I'll do what I list. What
Are these two? Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: You see they wear
Their heraldry.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: But I mean can they roar,
Beat drawers, play at dice, and court their mistress.
I mean forthwith to get a mistress.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: But
how comes this, mr.Timothy, you did not
Rise such a gallant this morning.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: All's on for that.
My mother lost her maidenhead that I
Might come first into th' world; and by God's lid
I'll bear myself like the elder brother, I.
D'ye think I'll all days of my life frequent
Saint Antlin, like my sister? Gentlemen
I covet your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Your servant, sir.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: I shall be proud to know you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Sir, my knowledge
Is not much worth; I me born to a small fortune,
Some hundred thousand pound, if once my father
Held up his hands in marble, or kneeled in brass.
What are you inns of court-men?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: The catechism
Were false should we deny it.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I shall shortly
Be one myself, I learn to dance already,
And wear short cloaks; I mean in your next masque
To have a part, I shall take most extremely.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: You will inflame the ladies, sir. They'll strive
Who shall most privately convey jewels.
Into your hand.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: This is an excellent fellow;
Who is't?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Rich Seathrift's son that's gone to sea
This morning with my uncle.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Is this he
Whose sister thou shouldst marry? The wench that brings
Ten thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: My uncle would fain have me,
But I have cast her off.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Faith she's handsome,
And had a good wit, but her schoolmistress
Has made her a rank Puritan.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Let's take him
Along with us and captain Quartfield shall show him.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: 'Twill be an excellent comedy, and afterwards
I have a project on him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Gentlemen
Shall we dine at an ordinary? You
Shall enter me among the wits.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Sir, I
Will but shift clothes then we'll associate you.
But first you shall with us and see a lady,
Rich as your father's chests and odd holes; and
Fresh as Pygmalion's mistress newly wakened
Out of her alabaster.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Lead on;
I long to see a lady and to salute her.

div.head: Scaena i.
div.l: Why we shall have you get in time the turn
Up of your eyes, speak in the nose, draw sighs
Of an ell long, and rail at discipline.
Would I could hear from Baneswright, ere I'll be tortured
With your preciseness thus, I'll get dry palms
With starching, and put on my smocks myself.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Surely you may, and air 'em too, there have been
Very devout and holy women that wore
No shift at all.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Such saints you mean as wore
Their congregations, and swarmed with Christian vermin.
You'll hold clean linen heresy?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Surely yes,
Clean linen in a surplice; that and powders
Do bring dry summers, make the sickness rage,
And th' enemy prevail, it was revealed
To Ms scruple and her husband, who
Do verily ascribe the German war,
And the late persecutions, to curling,
False teeth, and oil of talc.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Now she is in
A lecturer will sooner hold his peace
Then she.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And surely, as master scruple says,

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: That was her schoolmaster. One that cools a feast
With his long grace, and sooner eats a capon
Then blesses it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And proves it very well
Out of a book that suffered martyrdom
By fire in Cheapside, since amulets, and bracelets,
And lovelocks were in use, the price of sprats,
Jerusalem artichokes, and holland cheese,
Is very much increased, so that the brothers,
Butchers I mean, and such poor zealous saints,
As earn five groats a week under a stall,
By singing psalms, and drawing up of holes,
Can't live in their vocation, but are fain
To turn —

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Old breeches.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Surely, teachers and prophets.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O Mr. Baneswright, are you come? my woman
Was in her preaching fit, she only wanted
A table's end.

sp.speaker: Banesw.
sp.l: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Never
Poor lady had so much unbred holiness
About her person; I am never dressed
Without a sermon, but am forced to prove
The lawfulness of curling irons before
She'll crisp me in a morning; I must show
Text for the fashions of my gowns, she'll ask
Where jewels are commanded, or what lady
Ith' primitive times wore ropes of pearl or rubies;
She will urge counsels for her little ruff
Called in Northamptonshire ; and her whole service
Is a mere confutation of my clothes.

sp.speaker: Banesw.
sp.l: Why madam, I assure you time hath been
However she be otherwise, when she had
A good quick wit, and would have made to a lady
A serviceable sinner.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: She can't preserve
(The gift for which I took her) but (As though
She were inspired from Ipswitch) she will make
The acts and monuments in sweetmeats; quinces
Arraigned and burned at a stake; all my banquets
Are persecutions, and Dioclesian's days
Are brought for entertainment, and we eat martyrs.

sp.speaker: Banesw.
sp.l: Madam she is far gone.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nay, sir, she is
A Puritan at her needle too.

sp.speaker: Banesw.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: She works religious petticoats; for flowers
She'll make church histories; her needle doth
So sanctify my cushionets, besides
My smock-sleeves have such holy embroideries,
And are so learned, that I fear in time
All my apparel will be quoted by
Some pure instructor. Yesterday I went
To see a lady that has a parrot, my woman
While I was in discourse converted the fowl.
And now it can speak naught but Knox's works,
So there's a parrot lost.

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: Faith madam she
Was earnest to come to you, had I known
Her mistress had so bred her I would first
Ha preferred her to new England.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Surely, sir,
You promised me when you did take my money
To help me to a faithful service, a lady
That would be saved. Not one that loves profane,
Unsanctified fashions.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Fly my sight
You goody Hofman, and keep your chamber till
You can provide yourself some cure, or I
Will forthwith excommunicate your zeal,
And make you a silent waiting woman.

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: Ms Dorcas,
If you'll be usher to that holy learned woman
That can heal broken shins, scald heads, and th' itch,
Your schoolmistress, that can expound, and teaches
To knit in Chaldee, and work hebrew samplers,
I'll help you back again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The motion sure is good
And I will ponder of it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: From thy zeal,Ex. Dorcas.
The frantic lady's judgements, and Histriomastix,
Deliver me. This was of your preferring,
You must needs help me to another.

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: How
Would you desire her qualified, deformed
And crooked like some ladies, who do wear
Their women like black patches to set 'em of?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I need no foil, nor shall I think I'm white
Only between two Moors; or that my nose
Stands wrong, because my woman's doth stand right.

sp.speaker: Banes
sp.l: But you would have her secret, able to keep
Strange sights from th' knowledge of your knight when you
Are married, madam, of a quick feigning head?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You wrong me, Baneswright, she whom I would have,
Must to her handsome shape have virtue too.

sp.speaker: Banesw.
sp.l: Well madam I shall fit you. I do know
A choleric lady which within these three weeks
Has, for not cutting her corns well, put off
Three women; and is now about to part
With th' fourth, just one of your description.
Next change oth' moon, or weather, when her feet
Do ache again, I do believe I shall
Pleasure your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Expect your reward.

div.head: Scaena iii.
div.stage: To her bright, Newcut, Timothy, Plotwell.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Lady, let me taste the Elysium of your lips.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Why what are you? you will not leap me, sir,
Pray know your distance.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: What am I sweet lady?
My father is an alderman's fellow, and I
Hope to be one in time.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then, sir, in time
You may be remembered at the quenching of
Fired houses, when the bells ring backward, by
Your name upon the buckets.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Nay they say
You have a good wit lady, and I can find it
As soon as another: I in my time have been
Oth' university, and should have been a scholar.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: By the size of your wit, sir, had you kept
To that profession, I can foresee
You would have been a great persecuter of nature ▪
And great consumer of rush candles, with
As small success, as if a tortoise should
Day and night practise to run races: having
Contemplated yourself into ill looks,
In pity to so much affliction,
You might ha' passed for learned: and 't may be,
If you had fallen out with the Muses, and
Scaped poetry, you might have risen to scarlet.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Here's a rare lady with all my heart, by this
Light gentlemen, now have I no more language
Than a dumb parrot, a little more she'll jeer me
Into a fellow that turns upon his toe
In a steeple and strikes quarters.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: And why should you
Be now so dainty of your lips? verily
They are not virgins, they have tasted man.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And may again but then I'll be secured,
For the sweet air oth' parties. If you
Will bring it me confirmed under the hands
Of four sufficient ladies that you are
Clean men, you may chance kiss my woman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Lady,
Our lips are made of the same clay that yours,
and have not been refused.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Tis right you are
Two inns of court-men.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Yes, what then?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Known Cladders
Through all the town.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Cladders?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes, catholic lovers,
From country madams to your glover's wife,
Or laundress; will not let poor gentlewomen
Take physic quietly, but disturb their pills
From operation with your untaught visits.
Or if they be employed, contrive small plots
Below stairs with the chambermaid; commend
Her fragrant breath, which five yards of salutes,
At four deflowers a rose, at three kills spiders.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: What dangerous truths these are?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Ravish a lock
From the yellow waiting-woman, use stratagems
To get her silver whistle, and waylay
Her pewter knots or bodkin.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Pretty, pretty.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: You think you have abused us now?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I'll tell you,
Had I in all the world but forty mark,
And that got by my needle and making socks;
And were that forty mark mil-sixpences,
Spur-royals, harry groats, or such odd coin
Of husbandry as in the King's reign now
Would never pass, I would despise you.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Lady,
Your wit will make you die a withered virgin.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: We shall in time when your most tyrant tongue
Hath made this house a wilderness, and you
As unfrequented as a state's man fallen;
When you shall quarrel with your face and glass,
Till from your pencil you have raised new cheeks,
See you beg suitors, write bills o'er your door,
Here is an ancient lady to be let.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: You think you are handsome now, and that your eyes
Make star-shooting, and dart?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Tmay be I do.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: May I not prosper if I have not seen
A better face in signs, or gingerbread.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Yes, I for two pence oft have bought a better.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: What a sweet innocent look you have!

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Fie gentlemen,
Abuse a harmless lady thus, I can't
With patience hear your blasphemies. Make me
Your second madam.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And make me your third.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O prodigy to hear an image speak.
Why, sir, I took you for a mute ith' hangings.
I'll tell the faces.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Gentlemen do I
Look like one of them Trojans?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Tis so, your face
Is missing here, sir, pray step back again
And fill the number; you I hope have more
Truth in you then to filch yourself away,
And leave my room unfurnished.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: By this light
She'll send for a constable straight and apprehend him
For the every.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Why lady do you think me
Wrought in a loom, some Dutch piece weaved at Mooreclack ▪

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Surely you stood so simply, like a man
Penning of recantations, that I suspected
Y' had been a part of the monopoly.
But now I know you have a tongue, and are
A very man, I'll think you only dull,
And pray for better utterance.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Lady you make
Rash judgement of him, he was only struck
With admiration of your beauty.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Truly
And so I was.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then you can wonder, sir?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Yes when he sees such miracles as you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And love me can't you?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Love you? By this hand
I'd love a dog of your sweet looks; I am
Enamoured of you lady.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, now surely
I wonder you wear not a cap; your case
Requires warm things, I'll send you forth a caudle. Exit.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: The plague of rotten teeth, wrinkles, loud lungs
Be with you madam.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Had I now pen and ink,
If I were urged I'd fain know whether I
In conscience ought not to set down myself
No wiser than I should be.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Gentlemen
How like you her wit?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Wit? I verily
Believe she was begotten by some wit;
And he that has her, may beget plays on her.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Her wit had need be good ▪ it finds her house.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Her house? 'tis able to find the court, if she
Be chaste to all this wit, I do not think
But that she might be shown.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: She speaks with salt,
And has a pretty scornfulness, which now
I've seen I'm satisfied.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Come then away;
To Roseclap's.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Lead on, let us dine: this lady
runs in my head still.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.l: Sir, my lady prays. Enter a footman.
You would dismiss your company, she has
Some business with you.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Gentlemen walk softly,
I'll overtake you.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Newcut 'slight her wit
Is come to private meetings.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Ay, i thought
She had some other virtues. Well make haste,
We'll stay without, when thou hast done inform us
What the rate is; if she be reasonable
We'll be her customers.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: You're merry, sir.

div.head: Scaena iv.
div.l: Nay sister you may enter, they are gone.
I did receive your ticket this morning. What?
You look the mine should run still?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O you are
A careful brother, to put me on a course
That draws the eyes oth' town upon me, and makes me
Discourse for ordinaries, then leave me in't.
I will put off my ladyship, and return
To m' holland, and to making shirts,
And bands again.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I hope you will not.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I
Repent I left th' exchange.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Faith I should laugh
To see you there again, and there serve out
The rest of your indentures, by managing
Your needle well, and making nightcaps, by
A chafing dish in winter mornings, to keep
Your fingers pliant. How rarely 'twould become you
To run o'er all your shop to passengers
In a fine sale tune?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What would you have me do?
D'ye think I'm the Dutch virgin that could live
By th' scent of flowers? Or that my family
Are all descended of chameleons,
And can be kept with air? Is this the way
To get a husband to be in danger to be
shut up for house-rent, or to wear a gown
Out a whole fashion, or the same jewels twice?
Shortly my neighbours will commend my clothes,
For lasting well, give them strange dates, and cry
Since your last gorget and the blazing star.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Prithee excuse me sister, I can now
Rain showers of silver into thy lap again;
My uncle's gone to sea, and has left me
The key to th' golden fleece. Thou shalt be still.
A madam, pen, and to maintain thy honour,
And to new dub thee take this. But sister, IGives her a purse.
Expected you ere this out of the throng
Of suitors that frequent you, should have been
Made a true lady, not one in type or show.
I fear you are too scornful, look too high.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Faith brother 'tis no age to be put off
With empty education; few will make jointures
To wit or good parts. I may die a virgin,
When some old widow which at every cough
Resigns some of her teeth, and every night
Puts off her leg as duly as French hood,
Scarce wears her own nose, hath no eyes but such
As she first bought in Broad-street, and every morning
Is put together like some instrument,
Having full coffers shall be wooed, and thought
A youthful bride.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Why sister will you like
A match of my projection? you do know
How ruinous our father's fortunes are;
Before he broke you know there was a contract
Between you and young Seathrift. what if I
Make it a wedding?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Marry a fool? in hope
To be a lady majoress?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Why sister, I
Could name good ladies that are fain to find
Wit for themselves and knights too.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I have heard
Of one whose husband was so meek, to be
For need her gentleman usher, and while she
Made visits above stairs would patiently
Find himself business at tre-trip ith' hall.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: He's only city bred, one month of your
Sharp conversation will refine him; besides
how long will't be ere your dissembled state
Meet such another offer?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well brother you shall
Dispose of my affections.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Then sometime
This afternoon I'll bring him hither ▪ do you
Provide the priest; your dining room will serve
As well as the church.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I will expect you.

div.head: Scaena v.
div.stage: Enter captain quart-field beating Roseclap. Salewit and Millicent labouring to part 'em.

sp.speaker: Quart
sp.l: Sirrah, I'll beat you into air.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Good captain.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: I will by Hector.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Murder, murder, help.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: You needy, shifting, cozening, breaking slave.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Nay, Mr. Salewit, help to part 'em.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Ask me for money, dog?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Oh! I am killed.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Help. Help.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Nay captain.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Men of my coat pay?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I'll call in neighbours. Murder. Murder.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Rascal
I'll make you trust and offer me petitions
To go oth' score.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Good, 'tis very good.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: How does thy head sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Away be quiet, mill.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Roseclap, you'll never leave this, I did tell you
Last time the captain beat you what a lion
He is being asked for reckonings.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: So you did
Indeed good Mr. Salewit; yet you must
Ever be foolish husband.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: What if we
Do owe you money, sir, is't fit for you
To ask it?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Well, sir, there is law; i say
No more, but there is law.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: What law you cur?
The law of nature, custom, arms, and nations,
Frees men of war from payments.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes, your arms captain,
None else.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: No soldiers ought to pay.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.l: Nor poets:
All void of money are privileged.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: What would you have,
Captains and poets, Mr. Salewit says,
Must never pay.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: No, nor be asked for money.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Still I say there is law.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Say that again,
And by Bellona i will cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: You long to see your brains out.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Why you mongrel,
You John of all trades, have we been your guests
Since you first kept a tavern, when you had
The face and impudence to hang a bush
Out to three pints of claret, two of sack
In all the world?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: After that, when you broke,
Did we here find you out, customed your house,
And helped away your victuals which had else
Lain mouldy on your hands?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You did indeed,
And never paid for't. I do not deny,
But you have been my customers these two years,
My Jack went not, nor chimney smoked without you.
I will go farther; your two mouths have been
Two as good eating mouths as need to come
Within my doors, as curious to be pleased
As if you still had eaten with ready money:
Had still the meats in season; still drunk more
Than your ordinary came to.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.l: And your conscience now
Would have this paid for?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Surely so I take it.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.l: Was ever the like heard?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: 'Tis most unreasonable
He has a hardened conscience. Sirrah, cheater,
You would be questioned for your reckonings, rogue.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Do you inform.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: I hear one oth' sheriffs
Paid for the boiling of a carp a mark.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Most unheard of exactions!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yet surely, captain.
No man had cheaper reckonings than yourself,
And Mr. Salewit here.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: How cheap?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I say
No more good captain; not to pay is cheap,
A man would think.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: Sir, doubt you reckon air,
And make it dear to breathe in your house, and put
The nose to charges?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Right, perfumed air, captain.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Is not the standing of the salt an item,
And placing of the bread?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: A new way, captain.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Is not the folding of your napkins brought
Into the bill?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Pinched napkins, captain, and laid
Like fishes, fowls, or faces.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Then remember
How you rate salads, Roseclap; one may buy
Gardens as cheap.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes, Mr. Salewit, salads
Taken from Euclid, made in diagrams,
And to be eaten in figures.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: And we must pay
for your inventions, sir.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Or you are damned,
Good captain, you have sworn to pay this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Peace you loud, bawling cur; do you disgrace me
Before these gallants, see if I don't kill you.

div.head: Scaena vi.
div.stage: To them bright. Newcut. Timothy. Plotwell.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Save you captain Quartfield, and my brave wit,
My man of Helicon, salute this gentleman,
He is a city wit.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: A corporation
Went to the bringing of him forth.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: I embrace him;

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: And so do I.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: You are a poet, sir,
And can make verses, I hear?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Sir, I am
A servant to the Muses.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I have made
Some speeches, sir, in verse, which have been spoke
By a green robin goodfellow from Cheapside conduit,
To my father's company; and mean this afternoon
To make an epithalamium upon my wedding.
A lady fell in love with me this morning,
Ask Mr. Francis here.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Heart you spoil all,
Did not I charge you to be silent?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: That's true,
I had forgotten. you are a captain, sir?

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: I have seen service, sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Captain I love
Men of the sword, and buff, and if need were
I can roar too, and hope to swear in time,
Do you see, captain.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Nay captain we have brought you
A gentleman of valour who has been
In Moorfields often, marry it has been
To squire his sisters, and demolish custards
At Pimlico.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Afore me, Mr. Plotwell,
I never hoped to see you in silk again.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: I looked the next lord mayor's day to see you oth' livery,
Or one oth' bachelor whifflers.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: What is
Your uncle dead?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: He may in time; he's gone
To sea this morning, captain, and i am come
Into your order again. But hark you, captain,
What think you of a fish now?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Mad wags, mad wags.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: By heaven its true, here we have brought one with us.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Rich Seathrift's son, he'll make a rare sea-monster.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: And shall's be merry i'faith?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Salewit shall make
A song upon him.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: And Roseclap's boy shall sing it.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: We have the properties of the last fish.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: And if I
At dinner do not give him sea enough,
And afterwards if I, and Salewit do not
Show him much better than he that shows the tombs,
Let me be turned into a swordfish myself.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: A natural change for a captain. How now Roseclap,
Pensive and cursing the long vacation?
Thou lookest as if thou meanst to break shortly.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Ask
The captain why I am sad.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Faith gentlemen,
I disciplined him for his rudeness.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Why these
Are judgements, Roseclap, for dear reckonings.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Art thou
The half crown fellow of the house?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Sir, I
Do keep the ordinary.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Let's have wine enough;
I mean to drink a health to a lady.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Still
Will you betray your fortune? One of them
Will go and tell her who you are, and spoil
The marriage.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: No, peace. Gentlemen if you'll
Go in we'll follow.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Please you enter, dinner
Shall straight be set upon the board.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: We'll expect you,Ex: Br. New. Salew. quart. Rosecl.
Come gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: But Mr. Francis, was that
The business why she called you back.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Believe it
Your mother's smock shined at your birth, or else
You wear some charm about you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Not I truly.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: It can not be she should so strangely dote
Upon you else: slight had you stayed, I think
She would have wooed you herself.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Now I remember
One read my fortune once, and told my father
That I should match a lady.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: How things fall out?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And did she ask you who I was?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I told her
You were a young knight.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Scarce come to th' years
Of your discretion yet.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Good still.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: And that a great man
Did mean to beg you for his daughter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Most rare.
This afternoon's the time?

sp.speaker: Plotw
sp.l: Faith she
Looks you should use a little courtship first,
That done, let me alone to have the priest
In readiness.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: But were I not best ask
my friends consent?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: How? Friend's consent? that's fit
For none but farmer's sons, and milkmaids. You shall not
Debase your judgement. She takes you for a wit,
And you shall match her like one.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Then I will.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: But no more words to th' gallants.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Do you think
I am a sieve and cannot hold.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: GentlemenEnter Roseclap.
The company are sat.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: It shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Nay, sir, your fortune claims precedency. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Fetched abroad by two gallants say you?

sp.speaker: Cy.
sp.l: Yes, sir,
As soon as you were gone; he only stayed
To put on other clothes.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: You say my son
Went with 'em too?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And whether went they?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: I followed 'em to Roseclap's ordinary

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: And there you left 'em?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Yes, sir, just before
I saw some captains enter.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Well, I give
My son for lost, undone, past hope.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: There is
No more but this we'll thither straight. You cypher
Have your instructions.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Sir, let me alone
To make the story doleful.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Go, make you ready then ▪
Now, Mr. Seathrift, you may see, what theseExit.
Young men would do left to themselves.

sp.speaker: Sea-th.
sp.l: My son
Shall know he has a sister.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: And my nephew
That once he had an uncle. To leave land
Unto an unthrift is to build on sand.

div.head: Scaena i.
div.stage: Bright. Newcut. Plotwell. Rosclap. hanging out the picture of a strange fish.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Fore Jove the captain foxed him rarely.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: O sir
He is used to it; this is the fifth fish now
That he hath shown thus. One got him twenty pound.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: How Rosclap?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why the captain kept him, sir,
A whole week drunk, and showed him twice a day.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: It could not be like this.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Faith I do grant
This is the strangest fish. you I have hung
His other picture into th'fields, where some
Say 'tis an o'ergrown porpoise; others say
'Tis the fish caught in Cheshire; one to whom
The rest agree, said 'twas a mermaid.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: 'Slight,
Roseclap, shalt have a patent of him. The birds
Brought from Peru, the hairy wench, the camel,
The elephant, dromedaries, or Windsor castle,
The woman with dead flesh, or she that washes,
Threads needles, writes, dresses her children, plays
Oth' virginals with her feet, could never draw
People like this.

sp.speaker: New
sp.l: O that his father were
At home to see him.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Or his mother come,
Who follows strange sights out of town, and went
To Branford to a motion.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Bid the captain hasten,
Or he'll recover and spoil all.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: They're here.

div.head: Scaena. Ii.
div.stage: enter Quartfield and Salewit dressed like two trumpeters, keeping the door mrs.Seathrift and mrs Holland with a prentice before 'em as comers in.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: Bearback there.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.l: Pray you do not press so hard.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: Make room for the two gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Seath.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Twelvepence a piece
We will not give't. Q. make room
For them that will then.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: O fortune here's his mother.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: And who's the other?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: One Ms holland, the
Great seamstress on th'exchange
We gave but a groat
To see the last fish.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: Gentlewoman, that
Was but an Irish sturgeon.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: This came from
The Indies, and eats five crowns a day in fry,
Ox livers, and brown past
Well there's three shillings,
Pray let us have good places now.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Bear back there
Look mrs.Seathrift here be gentlemen.
Sure 'tis a rare fish
I know one of 'em,
And so do I, his sister was my prentice
Let's take acquaintance with him.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Hath the sight drawn you hither?
Yes sir I
And mrsholland here, my gossip, passed
This way and so called in. Pray, Mr. Plotwell,
Is not my son here? I was told he went
With you this morning.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: You shall see him straight.

sp.speaker: Ms Holl.
sp.l: When will the fish begin, sir?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Heart she makes him
A puppet play.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Why now they only stay
For company, 't has sounded twice.

sp.speaker: Ms Seath.
sp.l: Indeed
I long to see this fish; i wonder whether
They will cut up his belly, they say a tench
Will make him whole again.

sp.speaker: Ms Holl.
sp.l: Look Ms Seathrift,
What claws he has.

sp.speaker: Ms Seath.
sp.l: For all the world like crabs.

sp.speaker: Ms Holl.
sp.l: Nay mark his feet too.

sp.speaker: Ms Seath.
sp.l: For all the world like plaice.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Was ever better sport heard?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Prithee peace.

sp.speaker: Ms Holl.
sp.l: Pray can you read that? Sir, I warrant you,
That tells where it was caught, and what fish 'tis.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Within this place is to be seen,
A wondrous fish. God save the Queen
Amen, she is my customer, and I
Have sold her bonelace often.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Why the Queen?
'Tis writ the King.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: That was to make the rhyme.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Slid thou didst read it as 'twere some picture of
An Elzabeth fish.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Bear back there.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Make room, you
Friend that were going to cut a purse there, make
way for the two old gentlemen to pass. Enter Warehouse and Seathrift disguised.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: What must we give?

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: We take a shilling sir.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: It is no less.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Pray God your fish be worth it.
What is't a whale you take so dear?

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: It is
A fish taken in the Indies.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: Pray dispatch then,
And shout, us quickly.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Pray forbear, you'd have
Your head broke cobbler.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: Yonder is my nephew
In his old gallantry.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Who's there too? my wife?
And mrs.holland? Nay I looked for them.
But where's my wise son?

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Mass I see not him.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Keep out sir.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Waterman you must not enter. Cypher presses in like a waterman.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: This is no place for scullers.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: I must needs
Speak with one Mr. Plotwell.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: You must stay.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Thrust him out.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: And one Mr. SeathriftThey thrust him out.
On urgent business.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: They are yet employed
In weightier affairs, make fast the door.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: There shall no more come in: come in boy.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Don't
They speak as if my son were in the room?

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Yes, pray observe and mark 'em.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
And gentlewomen, you now shall see a sight,Draws a curtain behind it Timothy asleep like a strange fish.
Europe never showed the like; behold this fish
Oh strange look how it sleeps.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Just like a salmon
Upon a stall in Fish-street
How it snorts too,
Just like my husband.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: 'Tis very like a man.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: T'has such a nose and eyes.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Why 'tis a man fish.
An ocean centaur, begotten between a Siren
And a he stock fish.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Pray where took ye him?

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: We took him strangely in the Indies, near
The mouth of Rio de la plata, asleep
Upon the shore just as you see him now.
How say y', asleep .

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: How? would he come to land?

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: 'Tis strange a fish should leave his element.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Ask him what things the country told us.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: You
Will scarce believe it now. This fish would walk you
Two or three mile oth' shore sometimes; break houses,
Ravish a naked wench or two, (For there
Women go naked) then run to sea again.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: The country has been laid, and warrants granted
To apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: I do suspect these fellows,
They lie as if they had patent for't.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: The company
should every one believe his part, would scarce
Have faith enough among us.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Mark again.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: The states of holland would have bought him of us
Out of a great design.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: They offered
A thousand dollars.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: You cannot enter yet. Some knock.

sp.speaker: Ware.
sp.l: Indeed? so much? pray what to do?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Why sir,
They were in hope in time to make this fish
Of faction 'gainst the Spaniard, and do service
Unto the state.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Why, sir, next plate-fleet
To dive, bore holes i'th bottom of their ships,
And sink 'em; you must think a fish like this
May be taught Machiavel, and made a state-fish;

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: As dogs are taught to fetch.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Or elephants
To dance on ropes.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: And pray what honour would
The states have given him for the service?

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: That,
Sir, is uncertain.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Ha made him some sea count;
Or't may be admiral.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Then, sir, in time,
Dutch authors that writ mare liberum,
Might dedicate their books to him?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Yes being
A fish advanced, and of great place. Sing boy.
You now shall hear a song upon him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Listen

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Do they not act it rarely?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: If 'twere their trade
They could not do it better.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Hear you that sir?

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Still I suspect.

sp.speaker: Ms Holl.
sp.l: I warrant you this fish
Will shortly be in a ballad.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Begin boy

div.head: Song.
div.l: We show no monstrous crocodile,
Nor any prodigy of Nile.
No remora that stops your fleet,
Like sergeants gallants in the street.
No sea-horse, which can trot or pace,
Or swim false gallop, post, or race.
For crooked dolphins we not care,
Though on their back a fiddler were.
The like to this fish which we show,
Was ne'er in Fish-street old, or new.
Nor ever served to'th' sheriffs board,
Or kept in souse for the major lord.
Had old astronomers but seen
This fish, none else in heaven had been

sp.l: The song has wakened him, look, he stirs.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O,
Captain — pox — take — you — captain
Hark he speaks.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Oh-my — stomach. -

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Se.
sp.l: I'll pawn my life
This is imposture.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O — o —

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Heart the captain
Did not give him his full load.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: Can your fish
Speak friends? the proverb says they're mute.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I'll tell you
You will admire how docile he is, and how
He'll imitate a man; tell him your name
He will repeat it after you; he has heard me
Called captain and my fellow curse sometimes,
And now you heard him say pox take you captain.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: And yesterday I but complained my stomach
Was over charged, and how he minds it?

sp.speaker: New
sp.l: Strange?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: I is it not?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: The towardness of a fish.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Would you think when we caught him he should speak
Drake, drake.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: And did he?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes and Hawkins;
A sign he was a fish that swum there, when
These two compassed the world.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: How should he learn
Their names i wonder.

sp.speaker: Salw.
sp.l: From the sailors.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: That may be.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He'll call for drink like me, or any thing
He lacks.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O-god-my-head. -

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: D'ye hear him?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.l: O,
Hostess — a — basin —

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Slid he'll spew.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: No matter.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: Nay i have seen him foxed, and then maintain
A drunken dialogue
Lord how i long
To hear a little. Pray try him with some questions,
Will you, my friend?

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Sometimes he will be sullen,
And make no answers.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: That is when he's angered,
Or kept from drink long.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: But I'll try him: Ms sea.
To see what creatures may be brought to.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: Tim,
You are drunk.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Plague take you captain — o — lord
You — made — me —

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: 'Sdeath my son's name.

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.l: Do you call him?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: He'll answer to no name but that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: And Tim,
What think you of a wench now?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O I'm sick
Where is she, o.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: I'll lay my life this fish
Is some confederate rogue.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: I drink to you, Timothy,
In sack.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O o.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: A health, Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I can drink
No more, o.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: What not pledge your mistress?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O,
Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: He is not in the mood now.
Sometimes you'd wonder at him.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: He is tired
With talking all this day. That and the heat
of company about him, dull him.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Surely,
My friends, it is to me a miracle
To hear fish speak thus.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: So, sir, 't has been
To thousands more.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Come now next Michaelmas,
'Tis five years we have shown him in most courts
In Christendom, and you will not believe
How with mere travelling and observation,
He has improved himself, and brought away
The language of the country.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: May not I
Ask him some questions?

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Sir, you may, but he
Will answer none but one of us
He's used,Knocking at door.
And knows their voices.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: He is so Mrs. now
We'll open door.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: Well my belief doth tell me
There is a mist before our eyes.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: I mar'le
My wise son missed this show.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: Good people, we
Do show no more today; if you desireThey draw the curtain before him.
To see, come to us in Kings-street tomorrow

sp.speaker: Ms Holl.
sp.l: Come gossip let us go, the fish is done.
By your leave gentlemen. Truly 'tis a dainty fish.

div.head: Scaena iii.
div.stage: Enter to them cypher like a waterman.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Pray which is Mr. Plotwell?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I'm he friend,
What is your business?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Sir, I should speak with
Young Mr. Seathrift too.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Sir, at this time,
Although no crab like you, to swim backward, he is
Of your element.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Upon the water?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: No
But something that lives in't. If you but stay
Till he have slept himself a land creature, you may
Chance see him come ashore here.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O — my — head —
O — captain — Mr. Francis — captain — o. —

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: That is his voice sir.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Death oh my soul my son?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: He is in drink, sir, is he?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Surely friend,
You are a witch, he is so.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Then I must tell
The news to you, 'tis sad.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I'll hear't as sadly.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Your uncle, sir, and Mr. Seathrift are
both drowned some 8 mile below Greenwich.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Drowned?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: They went ith' tilt boat, sir, and i was one
Oth' oars that rowed 'em, a coal-ship did o'er run us,
I scaped by swimming, the two old gentlemen
Took hold of one another, and sunk together.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: How some men's prayers are heard? we did invoke
The sea this morning, and see, the Thames has took 'em.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: It cannot be, such good news, gentlemen,
Cannot be true.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: 'Tis very certain, sir,
'Twas talk upon th' exchange.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: We heard it too
In Paul's now as we came.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: There friend, there is
A fair for you; I'm glad you scaped; I hadGives him many.
Not known the news so soon else.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Sir, excuse me,

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Sir, it is conscience; i do believe you might
Sue me in chancery.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Sir, you show
The virtues of an heir.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Are you rich Warehouse
Heir, sir?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Yes, sir, his transitory pelf,
And some twelve hundred pound a year in earth,
Is cast on me. Captain, the hour is come,
You shall no more drink. Ale, of which one draught
Makes cowards, and spoils valour; nor take off
Your moderate quart-glass. I intend to have
A musket for you, or glass cannon, with
A most capacious barrel, which we'll charge,
And discharge with the rich valiant grape of
My uncle's cellar, every charge shall fire
The glass, and burn itself ith' filling, and look
Like a piece going off.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: I shall be glad
To give thanks for you, sir, in pottle draughts,
And shall love Scotch coal for this wrack the better,
As long as I know fuel.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Then my poet,
No longer shall write catches, or thin sonnets,
Nor preach in verse, as if he were suborned
By him that wrote the whip, to pen lean acts,
And so to overthrow the stage for want
Of salt or wit. Nor shall he need torment
Or persecute his muse; but I will be
His god of wine t'inspire him. He shall no more
Converse with the five yard butler, who like thunder
Can turn beer with his voice, and roar it sour;
but shall come forth a Sophocles, and write
Things for the buskin. Instead of Pegasus,
To strike a spring with's hoof, we'll have a steel
Which shall but touch a but, and straight shall flow
A purer, higher, wealthier Helicon.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Frank, thou shalt be my Phoebus. my next poem
Shall be thy uncle's tragedy or the life
And death of two rich merchants.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
And now i'faith what think you of the fish?

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Why as we ought, sir, strangely.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: But d'ye think
It is a very fish?

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: 'Tis a man.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: This valiant captain and this man of wit
First foxed him, then transformed him. we will wake him
And tell him the news. Ho Mr. Timothy!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Plague take you captain.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: What does your sack work still?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Come you've slept enough.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Mr. Timothy!
How in the name of fresh cod came you changed
Into a sea calf thus?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: 'Slight, sir, here be
Two fishmongers to buy you; beat the price
Now you're awake, yourself.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: How's this? my hands
Transmuted into claws? my feet made flounders?
Arrayed in fins, and scales? arn't you
Ashamed to make me such a monster? pray
Help to undress me.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: We have rare news for you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: No letter from the lady I hope?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Your father
And my grave uncle, sir, are cast away.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: They by this have made a meal
For jacks and Salmon. They are drowned.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Fall down
And worship sea-coals, for a ship of them
Has made you, sir, an heir.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: This fellow here
Brings the auspicious news: and these two friends
Of ours confirm it.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: 'Tis too true, sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Well,
We are all mortal; but in what wet case
Had i been now, if I had gone with him.
Within this fortnight I had been converted
Into some pike, you might ha' cheapened me.
In Fish-street; i had made an ordinary,
Perchance at the mermaid: now could I cry
Like any image in a fountain whichHe feigns to weep.
Runs lamentations. O my hard misfortune!

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Fie sir, good truth it is not manly in you,He feigns to weep.
To weep for such a slight loss as a father.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I do not cry for that.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: No; but to think
My mother is not drowned too.

sp.speaker: Seath
sp.l: I assure you,
And that's a shrewd mischance.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: For then might I
Ha gone to th' counting house and set at liberty
Those harmless angels, which for many years
Have been condemned to darkness.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: You'd not do
Like your penurious father, who was wont
To walk his dinner out in Paul's, whiles you
Kept lent at home, and had, like folk in sieges,
Your meals weighed to you.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Indeed they say he was
A monument of Paul's.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Yes, he was there
As constant as Duke Humphrey. I can show
The prints where he sat holes ith' logs.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: He wore
More pavement out with walking then would make
A row of new stone-saints, and yet refused
To give to th' reparation.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: I've heard
Heed make his Jack go empty to cozen neighbours.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Yes, when there was not fire enough to warm
A mastic patch to apply to his wife's temples
In great extremity of toothache. This is
True, Mr. Timothy, is't not?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Yes. Then linen.
To us was stranger than to Capuchins.
My flesh is of an order with wearing shirts
Made of the sacks that brought o'er cutchyneele,
copperas, and indigo. my sister wears
Smocks made of curran-bags.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: I'll not endure it.
Let's show ourselves.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Stay hear all first.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Thy uncle
Was such another Plotwell; I have heard
He still last left th' exchange; and would commend
The wholesomeness oth' air in Moorfields, when
The clock struck three sometimes.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Surely myself,
cypher his factor, and an ancient cat,
Did keep strict diet, had our Spanish fare,
Four olives among three. My uncle would
Look fat with fasting; I ha' known him surfeit
Upon a bunch of raisins, swoon at sight
Of a whole joint, and rise an epicureThey undisguise.
From half an orange.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Gentlemen 'tis false.
Cast off your cloud. D'ye know me, sir?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: My uncle!

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: And do you know me, sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: My father!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Nay,
We'll open all the plot, reveal yourself.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: cypher the waterman!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Salewit away;Exit Qu. Salewit.
I feel a tempest coming.

sp.speaker: Ware.
sp.l: Are you struck
With a torpedo nephew?

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Ha you seen too
A Gorgon's head that you stand speechless? or
Are you a fish in earnest?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: It begins to thunder.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: We will make bold to take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Ware.
sp.l: What is
Your captain fled?

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Nay gentlemen, forsake
Your company?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Sir, we wave business.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Troth
It is not kindly done.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Now, Mr. Seathrift,Ex. Br. New.
You see what mourners we had had, had we
Been wracked in earnest. My grieved nephew here
Had made my cellar flow with tears, my wines
Had charged glass ordinance, our funerals had been
Bewailed in pottle draughts.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: And at our graves
Your nephew and my son had made a panegyric,
And opened all our virtues.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Ungrateful monster.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Unnatural villain.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: Thou enemy to my blood.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Thou worse than parricide.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Next my sins I do
Repent I am thy uncle.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: And I thy father.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: Death oh my soul, did i when first thy father
Broke in estate, and then broke from the counter
Where Mr. Seathrift laid him in the hole,
For debt among the ruins of the city,
And trades like him blown up, take thee from dust,
Give thee free education, put thee in
My own fair way of traffic; nay decree
To leave thee jewels, land, my whole estate,
Pardoned thy former wildness, and couldst thou sort
Thyself with none but idle gallants, captains,
And poets, who must plot before they eat,
And make each meal a stratagem? Then could none
But i be subject of thy impious scoffs?
I swoon at sight of meat; I rise a glutton
From half an orange; wretch, forgetful wretch;
Fore heaven I count it treason in my blood
That gives thee a relation. But I'll take
A full revenge. Make thee my heir? I'll first
adopt a slave, brought from some galley; one
Which laws do put into the inventory,
And men bequeath in wills with stools, and brass pots.
One who shall first be household stuff, than my heir.
Or to defeat all thy large aims I'll marry;
cypher, go find me Baneswright; he shall straight
Provide me a wife. I will not stay to let
My resolution cool. Be she a wench
That every day puts on her dowry, wears
Her fortunes, has no portion, so she be
Young and likely to be fruitful, I'll have her;
By all that's good I will; this afternoon;
I will about it straight.

sp.speaker: Se.
sp.l: I follow you. Ex. ware. Cyph.
And as for you Tim Mermaid, Triton, haddock,
The wondrous Indian fish caught near Peru,
Who can be of both elements, your sight
Will keep you well. Here i do cast thee off,
And in thy room pronounce to make thy sister
My heir; it would be most unnatural
To leave a fish land. Lass, sir, one of your
Bright sins and gills must swim in seas of sack,
Spout rich canaries up like whales in maps.
I know you'll not endure to see my Jack
Go empty, nor wear shirts of copperas bags,
Nor fast in Paul's, you. I do hate thee now,
Worse than a tempest, quicksand, pirate, rock,
Or fatal leak, I or a privy seal.
Go let the captain make you drunk, and let
Your next change be into some ape, ('tis stale
To be a fish twice) or some active baboon.
And when you can find money out, betray
What wench ith' room has lost her maidenhead;
Can mount to'th King, and can do all your feats,
If your fine chain, and yellow coat come near
Th' exchange, I'll see you, so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: NowEx. sea.
Were there a dextrous beam and twopence hemp,
Never had man such cause to hang himself.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I have brought myself to a fine pass too ▪ now
Am i fit only to be caught, and put
Into a pond to leap carps, or beget
A goodly race of pickerel ▪

div.head: Scaena. Iv.
div.stage: To them Quartfield. Salewit. Roseclap, and Baneswright.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: How now mad lads, what? is the storm broke up?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: What sad like broken gamesters? Mr. Timothy
'Slight who would think your father should lay weeles
To catch you thus?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: If ever I be drunk
With captains more —.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Where's bright and Newcut?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: They
Were sent for to the temple, but left word
They would be here at supper.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: They are sure friends,
To leave us in distress:

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: What a mad plot
These two old merchants had contrived, to feign
A voyage, than to hunt you out disguised,
And hear themselves abused?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: We heard all.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: If i had stayed they had paid me for a captain.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: They had a fling at me. But do you think
Your uncle in this furious mood will marry?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: He deeply swore it; if he do, the slight
Upon the cards, the hollow die, park corner,
And Shooter's hill are my revenue.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Yes,
And as for me, my destiny will be
To fight by th' day, carry my kitchen, and
Collation at my back, wear orderly
My shirt in course, after 't has been the shift
Of a whole regiment in the Low-countries.
And after all return with half a leg,
One arm perchance, my nose shot off, to move
Compassion in my father, who in pity
To so much ruin my be brought to buy
Some place for me in an hospital, to keep me
From bridges, hill-tops, and from selling switches. Ent. Rosecl.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yonder's your uncle at the field door talking
With Baneswright, as hot, and earnest for a wench,
As a recovered monsieur.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: What is this Baneswright?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: A fellow much employed about the town,
That contrives matches. One that brings together
Parties that never saw, or ever met,
till't be for good and all. Knows to a penny
Estates and jointures; I'll undertake he has
Now lying by him unprovided some twenty
Widows of all fortunes that want husbands,
And men that want wives, and at an hour's warning
Can make things ready for the priest.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Let us
Devise to get him hither and cross the match.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I have great interest in him, the fellow loves me.
Could I speak with him and draw him to be
An actor in't, i have a stratagem
That can redeem all, and turn the plotEnter Baneswright.
Upon these sage heads.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: By Minerva, look,
Here's Baneswright.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Mr. Baneswright!

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Save you gallants.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: You are employed I hear to find a wife out
For my young sprightly uncle.

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: Sir, he has
Retained me to that purpose. I just now
Came from him.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: And do you mean the match
Shall then proceed?

sp.speaker: Banesw.
sp.l: I have a leaguer wench
In readiness, he's gone to put himself
Into fit ornaments, for the solemnity.
I'm to provide the priest and licence, we go
Some two hours hence to church.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Death you pander.
Forbid the banes or I will cut your weezle;
And spoil your squiring in the dark; I've heard
Of your lewd function, sirrah; you prefer
Wenches to bawdy-houses, rascal.

sp.speaker: Banesw.
sp.l: Good, sir.
Threaten me not in my vocation.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Why Baneswright you can be but paid, say I
Procure the wench, a friend of mine; and double
Your bargain, such a fair reward methinks
Should make thee of my project. Thou dost know
My fortunes are engaged, and thou mayst be
The happy instrument to recover 'em.
Be my good angel once, I have a plot
Shall make thee famous.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: By Mars deny, and I
Will act a tragedy upon thee.

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
I am a friend to wit, but more to you, sir.
Of whose misfortunes I will not be guilty.
Though, then, your uncle have employed me, and
Have deeply sworn to wed this afternoon,
a wife of my providing, if you can
O'rereach the angry burgess, sir, and bring
His wisdom to the gin, show me the way
I'll help to lay the trap.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Now thou art
An honest hearted pimp, thou shalt for this
Be drunk in vine dee, rascal: I'll begin
A runlet to thee.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Gentlemen lets in,
I'll tell you my design; you, Salewit, must
Transform yourself to a French deacon. i
Have parts for bright and Newcut too. Mischief
Upon their absence.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: We'll send for 'em.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: And
For Mr. Timothy i have a project
Shall make his father everlastingly
Admire his wit, and ask him blessing.

sp.speaker: Quart.
sp.l: Come,
Let's in and drink a health to our success.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I'm for no healths unless the glass be less.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: I did commit her to your charge that you
Might breed her, mrs.scruple, and do require
Her at your hand. Here be fine tricks, indeed;
My daughter Susan to be stolen a week,
And you conceal it; you were of the plot,
I do suspect you.

sp.speaker: Ms Scru.
sp.l: Sir, will you but hear
Me meekly?

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: No, I'll never trust again
A woman with white eyes, that can take notes,
And write a comment on the catechism.
All your devotion's false; is't possible
She could be gone without your knowledge?

sp.speaker: Ms Scru.
sp.l: Will you
Attend me, Ms Seathrift? If my husband
To wean her from love courses, did not take
More pains with her then with his Tuesday lectures,
And if i did not every day expound
Some good things to her 'gainst the sin oth' flesh,
for fear of such temptations, to which frail girls
Are very subject, let me never more
Be thought fit to instruct young gentlewomen,
Or deal in tent-stitch. Who ere 'twas that seduced her,
She took my daughter Emlin's gown and ruff,
And left her own clothes: and my scholars say
She often would write letters.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Why 'tis right
Some silenced minister has got her: that i
Should breed my daughter in a conventicle!
Pray husband be appeased.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: You are a fool.
You hear her Ms could not help it.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Nor
Your son help being a fish.
Why, sir, was he
The first that was abused by captains?

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Go
You talk like prating gossips.
Gossips? slight
What gossips, sir?
What gossips are we? speak.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: I'll tell you since you'd know: my wife and you,
Shrill mrs.holland, have two tongues, that when
They're in conjunction, are busier, and make
More noise than country fairs, and utter more tales
Than blind-folks, midwives, nurses. Then no show
Though't be a juggler scapes you. You did follow
The elephant so long, and King of Sweden,
That people at last came in to see you. Then
My son could not be made a fish, but who
Should I find there much taken with the sight
But you two? I may now build hospitals,
Or give my money to plantations. Exit Seath.
Let's follow him, come mrs.scruple.
Just
As your Sue left her schoolmistress, my pen
Left me.
They'll come again i warrant you.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Sister 'tis so projected, therefore make
No more demurs, the life of both our fortunes
Lies in your carriage of things well ▪ think therefore
Whither you will restore me, and advance
your own affairs, or else within this week
Fly this your lodging, like unaccustomed sinners,
And have your coach-horses transformed to rent,
Have your apparel sold for properties,
And you return to cutwork. By this hand
If you refuse all this must happen.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well, sir,
Necessity which hath no law, for once
Shall make me oth' conspiracy, and since
We are left wholly to our wits, let's show
