The power and virtue of 'em; if your Baneswright
Can but persuade my uncle, I will fit
Him with a bride.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: The scene is laid already;
I have transformed an English poet into
A fine French teacher, who shall join your hands
With a most learned legend out of Rabelais.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: But for my true groom who you say comes hither
For a disguised knight, I shall think I wed
His father's countinghouse, and go to bed
To so much bullion of a man ▪ faith I've
No mind to him, brother, he hath not wit enough
To make't a lawful marriage.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: You're deceived,
I'll undertake by one weeks tutoring,
And carrying him to plays and ordinaries,
Engaging him in a quarrel or two, and making
Some captain beat him, to render him a most
Accomplished gallant. Or say he be born, sister,
Under the city planet, pray what wise lady
Desires to match a wise knight? you'd marry some
Philosopher now, that should every night
Lie with you out of Aristotle, and lose
Your maidenhead by demonstration.
Or some great statesman, before whom you must sit
As silent and reserved as if your looks
Had plots on foreign princes, and must visit
And dress yourself by Tacitus. what he wants
In naturals, his fortunes will make up
In honours, pen; when he's once made a lord,
Who'll be so saucy as to think he can
Be impotent in wisdom? She that marries
A fool, is an hermaphrodite, the man
and wife too, sister. Besides 'tis now too late,
He'll be here presently, and comes prepared
For Hymen. I took up a footman for him,
And left him under three tyremens hands, besides
Two barbers.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well, sir, I must then accept him
With all his imperfections, i have
Procured a sir John yonder.

sp.speaker: Plotw
sp.l: Who is't?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: One
That preaches the next parish once a weekEnter a footman
Asleep for thirty pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.l: Here is
A knight desires your ladyship will give
Him audience.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Tis no knight ambassador?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.l: He rather looks like a knight oth' sun.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: 'Tis he.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Let him come in.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: If you be coy now, pen,Ex. foot.
You spoil all.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well, sir, I'll be affable.

div.head: Scaena iii.
div.stage: To them Timothy fantastically dressed, and a footman.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Sirrah, wait me in the hall,
And let your feet stink there; your air's not fit,
To be endured by ladies.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: What quarrel with
Your footman, sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Hang him, he casts a scent
That drowns my perfumes, and is strong enough
To cure the mother or palsy. Do I act
A knight well?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: This imperiousness becomes you
Like a knight newly dubbed, sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: What says the lady?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Speak lower, I've prepared her, show yourself
A courtier now she's yours.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: If that be all
I'll court her as if some courtier had begotten me
Ith' gallery at a masque.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Madam, this gentleman
Desires to kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And lips too lady.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sir, you much honour both.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Ay, I know that,
Else I'd not kiss you. Yesterday i was
In company with ladies and they all
Longed to be touched by me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You cannot cure
The evil, sir, nor have your lips the virtue
To restore ruins, or make old ladies young?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Faith all the virtue that they have, is that
my lips are knighted. I am born, sweet lady,
To a poor fortune that will keep myself,
And footman, as you see, to bear my sword
In cuerpo after me I can at court,
If i would show my gilt ith' presence, look
After the rate of some five thousands
Yearly in old rends, and were my father once
Well wrapped in cerecloth, I could fine for sheriff.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Heart you spoil all.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: She verily believed
Y'had ne'er a father.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Lives your father, than sir?
That gentleman told me he was dead.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: 'Tis true,
I had forgotten myself, he was drowned, lady,
This morning, as he went to take possession
Of a summer house and land in the canaries.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Now you've recovered all.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Do you think I have
Not wit enough to lie?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Break your mind to her,
She does expect it.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: But lady this is not
The business which i came for.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I'm at leisure
To hear your business, sir.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Mark that.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Indeed,
Sweet lady, I've a motion which was once
Or twice this morning in my mouth, and then
Slipped back again for fear.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Coward's never won
Ladies, or forts, sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Say then I should feel
Some motions, lady, of affection; might
A man repair Paul's with your heart, or put it
Into a tinderbox?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: How mean you, sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Why is your heart a stone, or flint?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Be plain, sir,
I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Not understand me?
You're the first lady that ere put a man
To speak plain English; some would understand
Riddles, and signs; say i should love you, lady?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: There should be no love lost, sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Say you so?
Then by this air my teeth e'en water at you;
I long to have some offspring by you; we
Shall have an excellent breed of wits; i mean
My youngest son shall be a poet; and
My daughters, like their mother, every one
A wench oth' game. And for my eldest son,
He shall be like me, and inherit. Therefore
Let's not defer our joys, but go to bed
and multiply.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Soft, sir, the priest must first
Discharge his office. I do not mean to marryEnter Dorcas out of her Puritan dress
Like ladies in new England, where they couple
With no more ceremony than birds choose their mate
Upon saint Valentine's day.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Madam the preacher
Is sent for to a churching, and doth ask
If you be ready, he shall lose, he says,
His chrisom else.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O miracle! out of
Your little ruff, Dorcas, and in the fashion?
Dost thou hope to be saved?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray madam do not
Abuse me; i will tell you more anon.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Tell him she's coming.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sir, please you partake
Of a slight banquet?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Just as you are satExit Dorcas.
I'll steal the priest in.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: When you are joined,
Be sure you do not oversee, but straight
Retire to bed, she'll follow.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: 'Tis not three
O'clock ith' afternoon.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: 'Tis but drawing
Your curtains and you do create your night.
All times to lovers and new married folks
May be made dark.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I will then. By this room
She's a rare lady. I do almost wish
I could change sex, and that she might beget
Children on me.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Nay will you enter?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Lady,
Pray will you show the way.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Most city like,
'Slid take her by the arm, and lead her in.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Your arm sweet lady. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: But are you sure th' are they?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: I'll not believe
My treacherous eyes again, but trust some dog
To guide me, if i did not see his uncle
Coming this way, and Baneswright with him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Who,
The fellow that brings love to banes, and banes
To bare thighs about the town?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: The very same, sir;
The city Cupid that shoots arrows betwixt
Party and party. All the difference is,
he has his eyes, but they he brings together
Sometimes do not see one another till
Till they meet ith' church.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: What say you now if Warehouse
Should in displeasure marry?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: 'Tis so, this fellow
In's company confirms me. 'tis the very business
Why Plotwell has sent for us.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Here they come.
Prithee let's stand and overhear 'em.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Stand close then.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Madam Aurelia is her name?

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Her father
Was, sir, an Irish baron, that undid
Himself by housekeeping.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: As for her birth
I could wish it were meaner. As many knights
And justices of peace as have been of
The family are reckoned into th' portion;
She'll still be naming of her ancestors,
Ask jointure by the herald's book, and I
That have no coat, nor can show azure lions,
In fields of argent, shall be scorned; she'll think
Her honour wronged to match a man that hath
No scutcheons but them of his company,
Which once a year do serve to trim a lighter
To Westminster and back again.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: You are
Mistaken, sir. This lady as she is
Descended of a great house, so she hath
No dowry but her arms. she can bring only
Some leopard's heads, or strange beasts, which you know
Being but beasts, let them derive themselves
From monsters in the globe, and lineally
Proceed from Hercules' labours, they will never
Advance her to a husband equal to
Herself in birth, that can give beasts too. She
Aims only to match one that can maintain
Her some way to her state. She is possessed
What streams of gold you flow in, sir,

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: But can she
Affect my age?

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: I asked her that; and told her
you were about some threescore, sir, and ten;
But were as lusty as one of twenty, (Or
An aged eunuch)

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: And what replied she?

sp.speaker: Bans.
sp.l: She,
Like a true Lucrece, answered it was fit
For them to marry by the church book, who
Came there to cool themselves; but to a mind
Chaste and endued with virtue, age did turn
Love into reverence.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Or sir reverence.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Prithee observe.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Is she so virtuous then?

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: 'Tis all the fault she has, she will outpray
A preacher at stAntlins; and divides
The day in exercise; I did commend
A great precisian to her for her woman.
Who tells me that her lady makes her quilt
Her smocks before for kneeling.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Excellent creature!

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: Then, sir, she is so modest.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Too.

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: The least
Obscene word shames her, a lascivious figure
Makes her do penance; and she maintains the law
Which forbids fornication, doth extend
To kissing too.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: I think the time an age
Till the solemnity be passed.

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: I have
Prepared her, sir, and have so set you out!
Besides, I told her how you had cast of
Your nephew, and to leave no doubt that you
Would ere be reconciled, before she went
To church would settle your estate on her,
And on the heirs of her begotten.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: To make all sure,
We'll call upon my lawyer by the way,
And take him with us.

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: You must be married, sir,
At the French church, i have bespoke the priest;
One that will join you i'th right Geneva form,
Without a licence.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: But may a man
Wed in a strange tongue?

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: I have brought together
Some in Italian, sir, the language doth
Not change the substance of the match; you know
No licence will be granted, all the offices
Are beforehand bribed by your nephew.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Well,
Let's to the lady straight, to cross him, I
Would marry an Arabian, and be at charge
To keep one to interpret, or be married
in China language, or the tongue that's spokeExit Ware. and banes.
By the great cham.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Now Newcut, you perceive
My divination's true, this fellow did
Portend a wedding.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Plague oth' prognostication.
Who'd think that madam were the party?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: O sir,
She'll call this wit to wed his bags, and lie
With some Platonic servant.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: What if we
Before we go to Plotwell, went to her
And strived to dissuade her?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Let's make haste,
They'll be before us else.

div.head: Scaena. Vi.
div.stage: Enter Timothy unbuttoning himself. Aurelia. Plotwell. Dorcas. Footman.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: By this hand lady you shall not deny me:
Since we are coupled, I shall think the priest
Has not done all, as long as I'm a virgin.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Will you not stay till night, sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Night? No faith,
I've sworn to get my first child by day, you may
Be quick by night.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Madam, your knight speaks reason.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I will both speak and do it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well sir, since
There is no remedy, your beds prepared;
By that time you are laid I'll come, mean time
I'll pray that gentleman to conduct you, there's
My footman to pluck of your stockings.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Sweet lady stay not long.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: I'll promise for her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Faith I admire your temperance to letEx. Tim. Pl. and Footman.
Your bridegroom go to bed and you not follow.
Were i in your case i should ha' gone first,
And warmed his place.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well wench but that thou hast
Revealed thyself unto me, I'd admire
To hear a saint talk thus. To one that knows not
The mystery of thy strange conversion, thou
Wouldst seem a legend.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Faith I have told you all,
Both why I left my schoolmistress, who taught me
To confute curling-irons, and why I put
Myself on this adventure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well wench my brother
has had his plots on me, and I'll contribute
My help to work thy honest ones on him.
Do but perform thy task well and thou winnest him.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.l: Let me alone; never was man so fittedEnter footman.
With a chaste bride, as I will fit his uncle. Exit.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.l: Madam your knight doth call most fiercely for you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Prithee, go tell him some business keeps me yet,
And bid him stay himself with this kiss.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: By your leave madam, what for practice' sake
Kissing your woman? Lord how a lady's lips
Hate idleness, and will be busied, when
The rest lies fallow, and rather than want action
Be kind within themselves, an't be t'enjoy,
But the poor pleasure of contemplation!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: And how do you find her madam?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Stay wench.
Does it not grieve you now, and make you sigh,

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Lord,
And very passionately accuse nature,
And say she was too hard to make your woman
Able to kiss you only and do no more?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Is it not pity but besides the gift
Of making caudles, and using of her pencil,
She had the trick oth' other sex?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Methinks
Your own good breeding might instruct you that
My house is not a new foundation, where
You might, paying the rate, approach, be rude,
Give freedom to your unwashed mouths.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My lady
Keeps no poor nuns that sin for victuals, for you,
With whom this dead vacation you may trade
For old silk stockings and half shirts. They say
You do offend oth' score, and sin in chalk,
And the dumb walls complain you are behind
In pension; so that your distressed vestals,
Are fain to foot their stockings, pay the brewer,
and landlords-rent in womankind, and long
More earnestly for the term than Norfolk lawyers.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Why you have got a second, lady, your woman
Doth speak good country language.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Offers at wit,
And shows teeth for a jest.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: We hear you are
To marry an old citizen.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then surely
You were not deaf.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: And do you mean his age,
Which hath seen all the kingdom buried thrice,
To whom the heat of August is December;Ex. Dorcas.
Who, were he but in Italy would save
The charge of marble vaults, and cool the air
Better than ventiducts, shall freeze between
Your melting arms? Do but consider, he
But marries you as he would do his furs,
To keep him warm.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: But he is rich, sir.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Then,
In wedding him you wed more infirmities
Than ever Galen wrote of; he has pains
That put the doctors to new experiments.
Half his diseases in the city bill
Kill hundreds weekly. Alone hospital
Were but enough for him.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Besides,
He has a cough that nightly drowns the bellman;
Calls up his family; all his neighbours rise
And go by it, as by the chimes and clock.
Not four loam walls, nor saw dust put between,
Can dead it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yet he still is rich.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: If this
Cannot affright you, but that you will needs
Be blind to wholesome council, and will marry
One who by th' course of nature ought to have been
Rotten before the Queen's time, and in justice
Should now have been some threescore years a ghost,
Let pity move you; in this match you quite
Destroy the hopes and fortunes of a gentleman,
For whom had his penurious uncle starved
And pined himself his whole life, to increase
The riches he deserves t'inherit it
Had been his duty.

sp.speaker: Aur
sp.l: You mean his nephew Plotwell;
A prodigal young man; one whom the good
Old man his uncle kept to th' inns of court,
And would in time ha' made him barrister;
and raised him to his satin cap, and biggin,
In which he might ha' sold his breath far dearer,
And let his tongue out at a greater price,
Than some their manors. But he did neglect
These thriving means; followed his loose companions,
His brights and Newcuts; two, they say, that live
By the new heresy Platonic love.
Can take up silks upon their strengths, and pay
Their mercer with an infant.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Newcut!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Ay,
I do observe her character; well than
You are resolved to marry?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Were the man
A statue, so it were a golden one,
I'd have him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Pray then take along to church
These few good wishes. May your husband prove
So jealous to suspect that when you drink
To any man you kiss the place where his
Lips were before, and so pledge meetings. Let him
Think you do cuckold him by looks; and let him
Each night, before you go to rest, administer
A solemn oath, that all your thoughts were chaste
That day, and that you sleep with all your hairs.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: And which is worse, let him forget he lay
With you himself, before some magistrate
Swear 'twas some other, and have it believed
Upon record.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Sister I've left your bridegroom,
Under this key locked in, to embrace your pillow. Enter Plotw.
Sure he has eat eringoes, he's as hot —
He was about to fetch you in his shirt.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: How's this? his sister?

sp.speaker: New
sp.l: I conceive not this.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: My noble friends, you wonder now to hear
Me call her sister.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Faith, sir, we wonder more
She should be married?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: If't be your sister, we
Have laboured her she should not match her uncle,
And bring forth riddles, children that should be
Nephews to their father, and to their uncle sons.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I laugh now at your ignorance: why these
Are projects, gentlemen; fine gins, and projects.
Did Roseclap's boy come to you?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: I have
A rare scene for you.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: The boy told us you were
Upon a stratagem.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I've sent for Roseclap,
and captain Quartfield to be here. I have
Put Salewit into orders, he's inducted
Into the French church, you must all have parts;

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Prithee speak out of clouds.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: By this good light
'Twere justice now to let you both die simple,
For leaving us so scurvily.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: We were
Sent for in haste by th' benchers, to contribute
To one of 'em that's reader.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Come with me,
I'll tell you then. But first I'll show you a sight
Much stranger than the fish.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Madam, here's Barneswright
And an old merchant do desire access. Enter Dorcas.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Bid 'em come in.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Gentlemen, fall off. Ex. Dorcas.
If we be seen the plot is spoilt. Sister,
Now look you do your part well.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I am perfect.

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: Madam, this is the gentleman i mentioned,
I've brought him here, according to my function
To give you both an interview; if you
Be ready, the church and priest are.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is this, sir,
The wealthy merchant?

sp.speaker: Banes.
sp.l: madam, this is he
That if you'll wear the price of baronies,
Or live at Cleopatra's rate can keep you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Come you a suitor, sir, to me?

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Yes lady,
I did employ my speaker there, who hath
I hope informed you with my purpose.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Surely,
Your speaker then hath erred; I understood
Him for my woman, if you can like her, sir,
It being for ought I hear, all one to you,
I've wooed her for you. But for myself, could you
Endow me with the stream that ebbs and flows
In waves of gold, i hope you do not think
I'd so much stain my birth as to be bought
To match into a company ▪ sir, plainly,
I'm matched already.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Baneswright, did not you
Tell me she'd have me?

sp.speaker: Banesw.
sp.l: Faith, sir, I have ears
that might deceive me, but I did dream waking
If she were not the party. madam, pray you
One word in private.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I'll prevent you; 'tis true,
My brother laid the scene for me, but since
We've changed the plot, and 'tis contrived, my woman
Shall undertake my part.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: I am instructed.
I was mistaken, sir, indeed the lady
Spoke to me for her gentlewoman. how
Do you affect her, sir? you see she is
As handsome as her lady, and her birth
Not being so high she will more size with you.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: I say, i like her best. Her lady has
Too much great house in her.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: 'Tis right, this you
May govern as you list. I'll motion't: lady,
Pray pardon our mistake, indeed our errand
Was chiefly to your gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sir,
She's one whose fortune i so much intend,
And yours, sir, are so fair, that though there be
Much disproportion in your age, yet i
Will overrule her, and she shall refer
Herself to be disposed by me.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: You much
Oblige me, madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Dorcas, this is the merchant
I have provided for you, he is old,
But he has that will make him young, much gold.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: madam, but that I should offend against
Your care as well as my preferment, i de
Have more experience of the man, i mean
To make my husband. At first sight to marry,
Must argue me of lightness.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Princes, Dorcas,
Do woo by pictures, and ambassadors,
And match in absent ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But
You look for some great portion, sir.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: Fair mistress,
Your virtues are to me a wealthy dowry.
And if you love me i shall think you bring
More than the Indies.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But, sir, 't may be
You'll be against my course of life. I love
Retirement, must have times for my devotion,
Am little used to company, and hate
The vanity of visits.

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: This makes me
Love you the more.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then i shall never trust you
to go to sea, and leave me; I shall dream
Of naught but storms, and pirates. Every wind
Will break my sleep.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I'll stay at home.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, there
Is one thing more; i hear you have a nephew,
You mean to make your heir. I hope you will
Settle some jointure on me.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: He's so lost
In my intents that to revenge myself,
I take this course. But to remove your doubts,
I've brought my lawyer with blank deeds,
He shall put in your name, and i, before
We go to church will seal 'em.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.l: On these terms
Where is your priest, sir?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: He expects me at
The French church, mistress.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Come, when you have sealed, sir,
I'll bear a part in the solemnity.

div.head: Scaena i.
div.stage: Plotwell. Aurelia. Bright. Newcut. Quartfield. Salewit. Roseclap. two footmen. Cypher.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Well sister, by this hand i was afraid
You had marred all; but I am well content
You have outreached me. If she do act it well now,
By Jove I'll have her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: She hath studied all
Her cues already.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Gentlemen, how do
You like the project?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Theirs was dull and cold
Compared to ours.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Some poet will steal from us
And bring't into a comedy.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: The jest
Will more inspire then sack.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: I have got cypher
Over to our side too; he has been up and downEnt. Salewit
To invite guests to th' wedding. How now Salewit, like a curate
Are they gone home?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: Yes faith, for better, for worse;
I've read a fiction out of Rabelais to 'em,
In a religious tone, which he believes
For good French liturgy. when i had done
There came a christening.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: And didst thou baptize
Out of thy Rabelais too?

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.l: No faith, i left 'em
in expectation of their pastor.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Newcut,
Who does he look like in that dress?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Hum? why
Like a Geneva weaver, in black, who left
The loom and entered into th' ministry
For conscience' sake.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Well gentlemen you all
Do know your parts, you captain, and Baneswright
Go get your properties. For you two, these
Two mules shall carry you in greater state,
And more ease than the fistula. you sister
We'll leave unto your knight, to come anon.
Roseclap and i will thither straight. You cypher
Know what you have to do?

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.l: And as for me
I'm an invited guest, and am to bless
The venison in French, or in a grace
Of broken English.

sp.speaker: Quartf.
sp.l: Before we do divide
Our army, let us dip our rosemaries
In one rich bowl of sack to this brave girl,
And to the gentleman that was my fish.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Captain you shall dip first.

div.head: Scaena ii.
div.l: My dearest Dorcas, welcome. Here you see
The house you must be mistress of, which with
This kiss I do confirm unto you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Forbear, sir.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: How wife, refuse to kiss me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, unless
A sweeter air came from you; y' have turned my stomach.
I wonder you can be so rude to ask me,
Knowing your lungs are perished.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: This is rare.
That I should live to this great age, and never
Till now know I was rotten!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I shall never
Endure your conversation; I hope you have
Contrived two beds, two chambers, and two tables;
It is an article that I should live,
Retired, that is, a part.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: But pray you wife
Are you in earnest.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: D'ye think I'll jest with age?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Will you not lie with me then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Did ever man
Of your hairs ask such questions? I do blush
At your unreasonableness.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Nay then —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is't fit i should be buried?

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: I reach you not.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why to lie with you were a direct emblem
Of going to my grave.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: I understand you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'll have your picture set in my wedding ring
For a death's head.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: I do conceive you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'd
Rather lie with an ancient tomb, or embrace
An ancestor than you. D'ye think I'll come
Between your winding sheets? For what? to hear you
Depart all night, and fetch your last groan? and
Ith' morning find a deluge on the floor,
Your entrails floating, and half my husband spit
Upon the arras?

sp.speaker: Ware.
sp.l: I am married —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then,
For your abilities, should twelve good women
Sit on these reverend locks, and on your heat,
And natural appetite, they would just find you
As youthful as a coffin, and as hot
As th' sultry winter that froze o'er the Thames;
They say the hard time did begin from you.

sp.speaker: Wareh.
sp.l: Good, I am made the curse of watermen.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your humours come frost from you, and your nose
Hath icicles in June.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Assist me patience.
Why hear you mistress, you that have a fever,
And dog days in your blood, if you knew this
Why did you marry me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: She laughs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That your experienced ache, that hath felt springs
And falls this forty year, should be so dull
To think i have not them that shall supply
Your cold defects.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You have your servants then?
And I am forked? hum?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do you think
A woman young, high in her blood —.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And hot
As goats, or marmosites —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Apt to take flame at
Every temptation —

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And to kindle at
The picture of a man —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would wed dust, ashes,
A monument, unless she were —

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Cracked, tried,
And broken up? —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Right, sir, or lacked a cloak?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Mischief and hell, and was there none to make
Your cloak but I?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Not so well lined.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O you
Stayed for a wealthy cuckold, your tame beast
Must have his guilded horns.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, sir, besides
Your age being impotent, you would I knew
In conscience wink at my stolen helps, if I
took comfort from abroad.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Yes, yes, yes, yes,
You shall be comforted, I will maintain
A stallion for you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will have friends come to me
So you'll conceal.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Alas, I'll be your pander;
Deliver letters for you, and keep the door.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'll have a woman shall do that.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O impudence!
Unheard of impudence!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then, sir, I'll look
Your coffers shall maintain me at my rate.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why like a lady; for I do mean
To have you knighted.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I shall rise to honour.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: D'ye think I'll have your factor move before me,
Like a device stirred by a wire, or like
Some grave clock wound up to a regular pace?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: No, you shall have your usher, dame, to stalk
Before you like a buskined prologue, in
A stately, high, majestic motion, bare.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I do expect it; yes, sir, and my coach,
Six horses, and postilion; four are fit
For them that have a charge of children; you
And I shall never have any.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: If we have,
All Middlesex is father.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then I'll have
My footman to run by me when I visit,
Or take the air sometimes in Hyde-park.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You,
Besides being chaste, are good at races too?
You can be a jockey for a need?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You're pleasant, sir.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why hark you, hark you, mistress, you told me
You loved retirement, loved not visits, and bargained
I should not carry you abroad.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You? no;
Is't fit I should be seen at court with you?
Such an odd sight as you, would make the ladies
Have melancholy thoughts.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You bound me too
I should not go to sea, you loved me so
You could not be without me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Not if you stayed
Above a year; for should I, in a long voyage,
Prove fruitful, I should want a father to
The infant.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Most politicly kind,
And like a whore perfect ith' mystery.
It is beyond my sufferance.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray, sir, vex,
I'll in, and see your jewels, and make choice
Of some for every day, and some to wearExit.
At masques.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: 'Tis very good. Two days.
Of this I shall grow mad, or, to redeem
Myself, commit some outrage — oh — oh — o.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Sir, I am sorry such a light offence
Should make such deep impressions in you; but that
Which more afflicts me then the loss of my
Great hopes, is, that you're likely to be abused, sir,
Strangely abused, sir, by one Baneswright. I hear
You are to marry.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Did you hear so?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Madam Aurelia's woman.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What of her, sir?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Why, sir, I thought it duty to inform you,
That you were better match a ruind bawd;
One ten times cured by sweating, and the tub,
Or pained now with her fiftieth ache, whom not
The power of usquebaugh, or heat of fevers
Quickens enough to wish; one of such looks,
That judges of assize, without more proof,
Suspect, arraign, and burn for witchcraft.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why pray?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: For she being passed all motions, impotence
Will be a kind of chastity, and you
Might have her to yourself, but here is one
Knows this to be —

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: An arrant whore?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I see
You have heard of her, sir; indeed she has
Done penance thrice.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How say you, penance?

sp.speaker: Rosc.
sp.l: Yes, sir,
And should have suffered —

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Carting should she not?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: The marshal had her, sir.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I sweat, I sweat.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: She's of known practice, sir: the clothes she wears
Are but her quarter's sins, she has no linen
But what she first offends for.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O blessed heaven
Look down upon me.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Nay, sir, which is more,
She has three children living, has had four.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How? Children? Children say you?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Ask him sir,
One by a French man.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Another by a Dutch.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: A third, sir, by a Moor; born of two colours.
Just like a sergeant's man.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why she has known then
All tongues and nations.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: She has been lain with farther
Than ever Coryat travailed, and lain in
By two parts of the map, Afrique, and Europe.
As if the state maintained her to allay
The heat of foreigners.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O — oh — oh — o.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: What ail you, sir?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O nephew I am not well,
I am not well.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: I hope you are not married.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: It is too true.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: God help you then.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Amen;
nephew forgive me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Alas good gentleman.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Would you trust Baneswright, sir?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: nephew in hell
There's not a torment for him; oh that I could
But see that cheating rogue upon the rack now:
I'd give a thousand pound for every stretch,
That should enlarge the rogue through all his joints,
And but just show him hell, and then recall
His broking soul, and give him strength to suffer
His torture often; i would have the rascal
Think hanging a relief, and be as long
A dying as a chopped eel, that the devil
Might have his soul by pieces. who's here? A sailor?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Are you, sir, Warehouse, the rich merchant?

sp.speaker: War
sp.l: Sir,
My name is Warehouse.

sp.speaker: Cy.
sp.l: Then you are not, sir,
So rich by two ships as you were.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How mean you?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Your two ships, sir, that were now coming home
From Ormus are both cast away; the wrack
And burden on the place was valued at
Some forty thousand pound. All the men perished,
By th' violence of the storm, only myself
Preserved my life by swimming, till a ship
Of Bristol took me up, and brought me home
To be the sad reporter.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Was nothing saved?

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Two small casks; one of blue figs, the other
Of pickled mushrooms; which served me for bladders,
And kept me up from sinking. 'twas a storm
which, sir, i will describe to you. The winds
Rose of a sudden with that tempestuous force —

sp.speaker: Vvar.
sp.l: Prithee no more; I have heard too much. Would I
Had been ith' tempest.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Good your worship give
A poor seafaring man your charity,
To carry me back again. I'm come above
A hundred mile to tell you this.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Go in,
And let my factor if he be come in,
Reward thee, stay and sup to.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Thank your worship.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why should I not now hang myself? Or ifEx. Cyp.
It be a fate that will more hide itself,
And keep me from discredit, tie some weight
About my neck, to sink me to the bottom
Oth' Thames, not to be found, to keep my body,
From rising up and telling tales. Two wracks?
And both worth forty thousand pound there? why
That landed here, were worth an hundred. I
Will drown myself; I nothing have to do
Now in this world but drown myself.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Fie these
Are desperate resolutions. Take heart, sir,
There may be ways yet to relieve you.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Why for your lost ships, say, sir, I should bring
Two oth' assurance office that should warrant
Their safe return, 'tis not known yet. Would you
Give three parts to secure the fourth?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I'd give
Ten to secure one.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Well, sir, and for your wife,
Say i should prove it were no lawful match;
And that she is another man's? you'd take
The piece of service well.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Yes, and repent
That when I had so good an heir begotten
Unto my hand, I was so rash to aim
At one of my own dotage.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Say no more, sir,
But keep the sailor that he stir not. we'llExit Plotwell and Roscl.
About it straight.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How much I was deceived
To think ill of my nephew. in whose revenge
I see the heaven's frown on me; seas and winds
Swell and rage for him against me. But i will
Appease their furies, and be reconciled.
Much joy to you, sir, you have made quick dispatch
I like a man that can love, woo, and wed,
All in an hour, my husband was so long
A getting me, so many friends consents
Were to be asked, that when we came to church
'Twas not a marriage, but our times were out,
And we were there made free of one another.
I looked to find you a-bed, and a young sheriff
Begotten by this. My husband, when I came
From church, by this time had his caudle; I
Had not a garter left, nor he a point.
Surely all that my husband did the first
Night we were married, was to call for one
Of his wrought caps more, to allay his rheum.
We hear you've matched a courtier, sir, a gallant;
One that can spring fire in your blood, and dart
Fresh flames into you.
Sir, you are not merry.
Methinks you do not look as you were married.
You rather look as you had lost your love.
Or, else as if your spouse sir, had rebuked you

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: How is it, sir? you feel have brought along
My fiddlers with me; my wife and mrs.holland
Are good wind instruments. 'tis enough for me
To put on sadness.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You, sir, have no cause.

sp.speaker: Seath.
sp.l: Not I? ask mrs.scruple. I have lost
My daughter, sir she's stolen. Then, sir, I have
A spendthrift to my son.

sp.speaker: Warch.
sp.l: These are felicities
Compared to me. You have not matched a whore, sir,
Nor lost two ships at sea.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Nor you, i hope.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Truth is you are my friends. I am abused,
Grossly fetched over. I have matched a stews;
The notedst woman oth' town.
Indeed i heard
She was a chambermaid.
And they by their place,
Do wait upon the lady, but belong
unto the lord.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: But is this true?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Here was
My nephew just now, and one Roseclap, who tell me
She has three children living; one dapple grey,
Half Moor, half English. knows as many men
As she that sinned by th' calendar, and divided
The nights oth' year with several men.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Bless me goodness!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then like a mad condemned to all misfortunes,
I have estated her in all I have.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Under hand and seal, sir, irrecoverably.
Look mrs.scruple here's your husband.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.l: Be
The leave of the fair company.
My husband?
His cold keeps him at home. surely i take
This to be some Dutch elder.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Were is
The breed an bridegroom? O, monsieur, I'm com't
To give you joy, and bless your capòn; were
Is your fair breed?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O Monsieur, you have joined me
To a chaste virgin. Would when i came to you
Y' had used your ceremonies about my funeral.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: funeral? Is your breed dead?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Would she were.
I'd double your fee, monsieur, to bury her.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Ee can but little English.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: No, i see
You are but new come over.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Dover? Tere
'E landed.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I, sir, pray walk in; that door
Will land you in my dining room.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Ee thank you. Exit.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: This is the priest that married us.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: This is
A Frenchman is't not?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: 'Twas at the French church.

div.head: Scaena vii.
div.stage: Enter to them two footmen bearing the frame of a great picture. Curtains drawn.

sp.speaker: 1 footman
sp.l: Set 'em down gently, so.

sp.speaker: 2 foe
sp.l: They make me sweat ▪
pictures quoth you? slight they have weight enough
To be the parties.

sp.speaker: 1 footman
sp.l: My lady, sir, has sent
A present to your wife.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What lady pray?

sp.speaker: 1 footman
sp.l: Madam Aurelia, sir.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O —

sp.speaker: 2 footman
sp.l: Sir, they are
A brace of pictures with which my lady prays
She will adorn her chamber.

sp.speaker: Ware.
sp.l: male pictures pray,
Or female?

sp.speaker: 1 footman
sp.l: Why d'ye ask?

sp.speaker: Ware-h.
sp.l: Because methinks
It should be Mars and Venus in a net,
Aretine's postures, or a naked nymph,
Lying asleep, and some lascivious satyr
Taking her lineaments. These are pictures which
Delight my wife.

sp.speaker: 2 footman
sp.l: These are night-pieces, sir,
Lord how I long to see 'em? I have at home
The finest ravished Lucrece!
So have I
The finest fall of Babylon! there is
A fat monk spewing churches, save your presence.
Pray will you open 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 footman
sp.l: My lady charged us
None should have sight of 'em, sir, but your wife.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Because you make so dainty, I will see 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 footman
sp.l: 'Tis out of our commission.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: But not of mine. Draws the curtain within are discovered bright. And Newcut.
Hell and damnation!

sp.speaker: 1 footman
sp.l: How d'ye like 'em, sir?
Look they are pictured in their clothes.
They stir too.

sp.speaker: 2 footman
sp.l: Sir, they are drawn to life; a master's hand
Went to 'em, I assure you.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Out varlets, bawds,
Panders, avoid my house. O devil! are youThey come out.
My wife's night-pieces?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Sir, you are rude, uncivil,
And would be beaten.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: We cannot come in private
On business to your wife, but you must be
Inquisitive sir? Thank God 'tis in your own house,
The place protects you.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: If such an insolence
Scape unrevenged, henceforth no ladies shallEnter Dor.
Have secret servants.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Here she comes, we'll ask
if she gave you commission to be so bold.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why this is far beyond example rare.
Now i conceive what is Platonic love,
'Tis to have men like pictures brought disguised,
To cuckold us with virtue. They whisper.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He would not offer't would he?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: We have been
In danger to be searched; hereafter we
Must first be questioned by an officer,
And bring it under hands we are no men,
Or have naught dangerous about us, before
We shall obtain access.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: We do expect
In time your husband to preserve you chaste,
Should keep you with a guard of eunuchs; or
Confine you, like Italians, to a room
Where no male beast is pictured, lest the sight
Of ought that can beget, should stir desires.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I mar'le, sir, who did licence you to pry,
Or spy out any friends that come to me;
It shows an unbred curiosity;
Which I'll correct hereafter, you will dare
To break up letters shortly, and examine
My tailor, lest when he brings home my gown
There be a man in't. I'll have whom I list,
In what disguise I list, and when I list,
And not have your four eyes so saucy, to peep,
As if you by prevention meant to kill
A basilisk.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Mistress, do what you list,
Send for your couch out, lie with your gallants there
Before us all. Or if you have a mind
To fellows that can lift weights, I can call
Two footmen too:

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: You are too patient, sir.
Send for the marshal, and discharge your house.
Truly a handsome woman, what pity 'tis
she is not honest?
Two proper gentlemen too.
Lord that such pictures might be sent to me.

div.head: Scaena ultima.
div.stage: Enter to them Plotwell and Roseclap. with Baneswright and Quartfield disguised.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O nephew welcome to my ransom; here
My house is made a new erection; gallants
Are brought in varied forms. Had I not looked
By providence into that frame, these two
Had been conveyed for night-pieces and lantskips
Into my chaste bride's chamber. Till now she took
And let herself out; now she will be able
To hire, and buy offenders.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: I'll ease you, sir.
We two have made a full discovery of her.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: She's married to another man, sir.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Good.
nephew thou art my blessed angel: who
Are these two?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Two that will secure your ships;
Sent by the office. seal you, sir, th' have brought
Th' assurance with 'em.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: nephew thou wert born
To be my dear preserver

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: It is duty, sir,
To help you out with your misfortunes. Gentlemen,
Produce your instruments. uncle put your seal,They subscribe seal and deliver interchangeably
And write your name here, they will do the like
To the other parchment. So, now deliver.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I do deliver this as my act and deed.

sp.speaker: Ban. Quart.
sp.l: And we this as our act and deed.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Pray gentlemen
Be witness here. Upon a doubtful rumour
Of two ships wracked as they returned from Ormus,
My uncle covenants to give three parts
To have the fourth secured. And these two hereSea. ros Br. New. subscribe as witnesses.
As delegates of the office, undertake
At that rate to assure them. Uncle now
Call forth the sailor, and send for the priestEnt. sale. ▪ cyph.
That married you.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Look here they come.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: First then,
Not to afflict you longer, uncle, since
We now are quit, know, all this was my project.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Your two ships are richly landed: if
you'll not believe me, here's the sailor, whoCyph. undisguises.
Transformed to cypher, can tell you.

sp.speaker: Cyp.
sp.l: 'Tis very true, sir.
I hired this travailing case of one oth' sailors,
That came in one of 'em. They lie at Blackwall.
Troth I in pity, sir, to Mr. Plotwell,
Thought it my duty to deceive you.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Very well, sir.
What are these masquers too?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Faith, sir, theseEx. cyph. they undisguise.
Can change their forms too. They are two friends
Worth threescore thousand pound, sir, to my use.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Baneswright, and captain Quartfield!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay old boy
Th' haste a good pennyworth on't. The jest is worth
Three parts of four.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Faith, sir, we hope you'll pay
tonnage and poundage into th' bargain.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O
You are a precious rogue, you ha' preferred me
To a chaste Lucrece, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Your nephew, sir,
Hath married her with all her faults, they are
New come from church.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Wonder not, sir, you
Were married but in jest. 'twas no churchform,
But a fine legend out of Rabelais.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: TrothSalw. undisguises.
This reverend weed cast off, I'm a lay poet,
And can not marry unless't be in a play,
In the fifth act, or so; and that's almost
Worn out of fashion too.
These are the two
That showed my son.
Let's have our money back.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: But uncle for the jointure, you have made her,
I hope you'll not retract. That and three parts
Of your two sips, besides what you will leave
Us at your death, will make a pretty stock
For young beginners.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Am I o'erreached so finely?

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: But are you married, sir, in earnest?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Troth,
We have not been a-bed yet, but may go,
And no law broken.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Then I must tell you, sir,
Y' have wronged me, and I look for satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Why? I beseech you, sir.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Sir, were not you
Betrothed once to my daughter?
And did not I,
And Ms holland help to make you sure?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: I do confess it.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Bear witness, gentlemen,
He doth confess it.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: I'll swear it too, sir.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Why
Then have you matched this woman?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Why? because
This is your daughter, sir, I'm hers by conquest,
for this day's service.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Is't possible I should
Be out in my own child so?

sp.speaker: Ms Sea.
sp.l: I told you husband.

sp.speaker: Ms Scru.
sp.l: Surely my spirit gave me it 'twas she.
And yet to see, now you have not your wire,
Nor city ruff on, mistress sue, how these
Clothes do beguile. In truth I took you for
A gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Here be rare plots indeed.
Why how now, sir, these young heads have outgone us.
Was my son oth' plot too?

sp.speaker: Plotw.
sp.l: Faith, sir, he
Is married too; I did strike up a weddingEnt. Tim. Aur.
Between him and my sister,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Look, sir,
They come without their maiden heads.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Why this
Is better still. Now, sir, you might have asked
Consent of parents.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Pray forgive me, sir.
I thought I had match a lady, but she proves —

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Much better, sir; I'd chide you as a fish
But that your choice pleads for you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Mother pray
Salute my wife, and tell me if one may not
Lie with her lips; nay you too, mr. holland;
You taught her to make shirts and bonelace; she's
Out of her time now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Holl.
sp.l: I release her, sir.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I took your sister for a lady, nephew.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: I kept her like one, sir, my temple scores
Went to maintain the title, out of hope
To gain some great match for her, which you see
Is come to pass.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Well, Mr. Seathrift, things
Are just fallen out as we contrived 'em; I
Grieve not I am deceived. Believe me, gentlemen,
You all did your parts well; 'twas carried cleanly;
And though I could take some things ill of you
Fair mistress, yet 'twas plot, and I forget it;
Let's in and make 'em portions.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Lead the way, sir.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: More revelations yet?

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: I all this while have stood behind the curtain;
You have a brother, sir, and you a father.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: If he do live, I have.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: He in his time
Was held the wealthiest merchant on th' exchange.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: 'Tis true, but that his shipwracks broke him.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: And
The debt for which he broke I hear you haveBaneswr. undisguises
Compounded.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: I am paid it.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Then I thank you.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: My brother Plotwell!

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Son I wish you joy.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: O my blessed stars! my father.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: And to you fair mistress
Let it not breed repentance that I have,
For my security to scape your father,
A while descended from myself to this
Unworthy shape. Now I can cast it off,
And be my true self. I have a ship which fame
Gave out for lost but just now landed too
Worth twenty thousand pounds towards your match.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.l: Better and better still.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Well what was wanting
Unto our joys and made these nuptials
Imperfect. Brother you by your discoveryEnter cypher.
Have fully added.

sp.speaker: Cyph.
sp.l: Sir, the two sheriffs are
Within and have both brought their wives.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The feast
Intended for my wedding shall be yours.
To which I add may you so love, to say
When old, your time was but one marriage day.

div.head: The epilogue at Whitehall.
div.l: The author was deceived, for should the parts,
And play which you have seen, plead rules and arts,
Such as strict critics write by, who refuse
T'allow the buskin to the comic muse,
Whose region is the people, every strain
Of royalty being tragic, though none slain:
He'd now, great sir, hold all his rules untrue,
And thinks his best rule is the Queen and you.
He should have searched the storeys of each age,
And brought five acts of princes on the stage.
He should have taken measure, and raised sport,
From persons bright, and glorious as your court ▪
And should have made his argument to be
Fully as high, and great as they that see.
Here, he confesseth, you did nothing meet
But what was first a comedy ith' street:
Cheapside brought into verse, no passage strange
To any here that hath been at th' exchange.
Yet he hopes none doth value it so low
As to compare it with my lord mayor's show.
'Tis so unlike, that some, he fears, did sit,
Who missing pageants did o'ersee the wit.
Since then his scenes no pomp or highness' boast,
And low things graced show princes princes most,
your royal smiles will raise't, and make him say,
He only wrote, your liking made the play.

div.head: The epilogue at Blackfriars.
div.l: Once more the author, ere you rise, doth say
Though he have public warrant for his play,
Yet he to th' Kings command needs the Kings writ
To keep him safe, not to b'arraigned for wit.
Not that he fears his name can suffer wrack
From them who sixpence pay, and sixpence crack.
To such he wrote not; though some parts have been
So like here, that they to themselves came in.
To them who call't reproof to make a face,
Who think they judge when they frown ith' wrong place;
Who if they speak not ill oth' poet, doubt
They lose by th' play, nor have their two shillings out,
He says, he hopes, they'll not expect he'd woo,
The play being done, they'd end their sour looks too.
But before you who did true hearers sit,
Who singly make a box, and fill the pit,
Who to his comedy read, and unseen,
Had thronged theatres, and Blackfriars been,
He for his doom stands; your hands are his bays;
Since they can only clap, who know to praise.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
